{{Infobox criminal | name = Frederick William Hahneman | image_size = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1922|7|5|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Puerto Castilla, Honduras]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1991|12|17|1922|7|5|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Costa Mesa]], [[California]], US | occupation =Engineer | spouse = Mary Jane Hahneman | children = Two sons | parents = Delia Pastore Ordóñez
William Frederick Hahneman | alias = George Ames | image_name = | image_caption = | charge = Aircraft Piracy, [[kidnapping]] and [[extortion]] | conviction_penalty = [[Life imprisonment]]. [[Parole]]d after 12 years. | }} '''Frederick William Hahneman''' (July 5, 1922 – December 17, 1991) was a Honduras-born US citizen convicted of hijacking [[Eastern Airlines]] Flight 175 from [[Allentown, Pennsylvania]] to [[Miami, Florida]], on May 5, 1972. Hahneman parachuted from the plane over his native [[Honduras]] after extorting $303,000 from Eastern Airlines. Evading a manhunt by the [[FBI]] and Honduran police and with a $25,000 bounty on his head, Hahneman went on the run for 28 days before finally surrendering to the US [[Embassy]] in [[Tegucigalpa]]. He was sentenced to life imprisonment for [[aircraft hijacking]], [[kidnapping]] and [[extortion]], serving 12 years. Speculation still surrounds Hahneman's motives for the crime. ==Background== Hahneman was born in [[Puerto Castilla, Honduras]], to a Honduran mother, Delia Pastore Ordóñez, and an American father, the late William Frederick Hahneman, of San Francisco. It is not known when he was naturalized{{fact|date=March 2016}} but he had lived in Easton, Pennsylvania, since 1960.The Dispatch, Lexington, N.C. 2 June 1972. Kurt Lassen, p12. He was an engineer and married to Mary Jane Hahneman. They had two sons.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. Neighbours of the couple told investigators later that Hahneman was a "mystery" to them and that Mary, going blind, raised the children alone.The Dispatch, Lexington, N.C. 2 June 1972. Kurt Lassen, p12. ==Historical context== The period 1967–1972 saw a spate of aircraft hijackings in the United States and worldwide. There had been 26 attempted hijackings in 1971 alone, 11 of them successful. So common were they that the May 8 ''[[Evening Chronicle]]'' editorial of 1972 stated, "They often command little more than one-column, six-paragraph stories on page 8 of most daily newspapers."The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. The hijackings were a mixture of [[terrorism]] and crime for profit. The most infamous of these hijackings is arguably that of [[D. B. Cooper]], which occurred just six months prior to Hahneman boarding Flight 175. ==The hijacking== On May 2, 1972 Hahneman checked into the Americus hotel in Allentown as a well dressed businessman under the assumed name George Ames. Staff remembered him as "polite" but got the impression that Ames had "put up a wall around himself". After asking directions to a travel agent, staff later reported Ames saying he was "going to take a plane" later that morning.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. [[File:ABE terminal (2).JPG|thumb|right|Main terminal at [[Lehigh Valley International Airport]], then known as A-B-E International.]] On the morning of May 5 at [[Lehigh Valley International Airport]] (known at the time as '''A'''llentown–'''B'''ethlehem–'''E'''aston International Airport), Hahneman managed to board Eastern Airlines Flight 175, a [[Boeing 727]] jet, armed with a handgun. Shortly after take-off, Hahneman threatened the crew and informed the pilot, Captain W.L. Hendershott, that he was taking over the plane and wanted $303,000 from the airline.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. While the captain informed the 48 passengers that "there is an armed man aboard", Hahneman held the chief stewardess hostage at the rear of the plane. One of the passengers, ''[[New York Times]]'' reporter Neil Amdur, wrote later, "From the moment the captain uttered those chilling words...I felt a sense of fear I had never known."The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. The captain would later tell FBI investigators that Hahneman "talked like there was another country and he wanted the money for a cause."The Encyclopedia of Kidnappings by Michael Newton, Checkmark Books; 1st edition (April 1, 2002), 129 Two other passengers, Frank Valek, a safety inspector for Western Electric, and Robert Palazzo, the mayor of Columbia, N.J., both found Hahneman's gun pressed into their stomachs as they went to the rest room and magazine rack, respectively. Other passengers prayed.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. Flight 175 was scheduled to land at [[Washington DC|Washington]]'s [[National Airport]] but Hahneman ordered the captain to land at [[Dulles International Airport]]. He did so at 11:15am. No passengers were allowed to leave the plane while Eastern Airlines worked to meet Hahneman's demands.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. These were $303,000 in cash, six parachutes, two bush knives, two jump suits, two crash helmets,The Encyclopedia of Kidnappings by Michael Newton, Checkmark Books; 1st edition (April 1, 2002), 129 fuel, foodThe Dispatch, Lexington, N.C. 2 June 1972. Kurt Lassen, p12. and two cartons of his favourite [[Benson and hedges|Benson and Hedges]]Wikileaks cable 1973STATE088847_b cigarettes.The Encyclopedia of Kidnappings by Michael Newton, Checkmark Books; 1st edition (April 1, 2002), 129 Satisfied that his demands had been met, at 1:13pm Hahneman allowed the passengers to disembark one by one, including one stewardess. The rest of the 6The Encyclopedia of Kidnappings by Michael Newton, Checkmark Books; 1st edition (April 1, 2002), 129 crew he kept hostage and ordered the captain to take off again at 1:50pm. Soon after becoming airborne Hahneman decided he didn't like the $100 bill denominations given to him by Eastern. He ordered the plane to return to Dulles and demanded the money in larger bills. It took Eastern four hours to comply with this difficult demand, with some of the bills being flown in from Miami.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. [[File:Rwr727tail.jpg|thumb|left|[[Boeing 727]] with the aft airstair open, Hahneman's means of escape.]] Satisfied once again, Hahneman ordered the captain to take off and fly to the [[Central American]] republic of Honduras, his country of birth. However, en route the plane's hydraulic pump developed a problem and the captain told Hahneman they had to divert to New Orleans. Hahneman was angry and when they landed in New Orleans he demanded another plane from Eastern. When it was ready he put a noose around Captain Hendershott's neck and forced the crew out at gunpoint,The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. using them as a human shieldThe Encyclopedia of Kidnappings by Michael Newton, Checkmark Books; 1st edition (April 1, 2002), 129 to get safely onto the new plane.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. The remainder of Flight 175 passed without incident and on May 6, around 4am, over the pitch dark Honduran jungle, Hahneman ordered the captain to slow the plane's airspeed. He put on one of the parachutes he'd demanded and opened the rear door. Clutching his money-filled attache case, Frederick Hahneman jumped from the aft airstair into the dense undergrowth below, and disappeared.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. ==Manhunt== In the US the story faded from the news but in Honduras, Hahneman was on the run from the FBI and the Honduran police. He moved around between friends and family, trying to stay one step ahead.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. Eastern Airlines put up a $25,000 reward for his capture leading to a tip off that Hahneman was still in Honduras.The Encyclopedia of Kidnappings by Michael Newton, Checkmark Books; 1st edition (April 1, 2002), 129 With his picture now everywhere in Honduras and exposure close, Hahneman sought refuge with his old friend and fellow engineer, José Gómez Rovelo.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. On June 1, Acting [[FBI Director]] [[L. Patrick Gray III]] obtained a warrant in the [[US District Court]] of Alexandria, Va., for Hahneman's arrest. The FBI had put together biographical information Hahneman had let slip to the crew during their 20-hour ordeal, with a photograph they possessed, to identify Hahneman as their prime suspect. They said Hahneman's movements in rural Honduras had been tracked by the Honduran police.The Dispatch, Lexington, N.C. 2 June 1972. Kurt Lassen, p12. With the net closing, Rovelo convinced Hahneman that he was too old to be on the run. Hahneman agreed. At 1am on June 2, Hahneman and Rovelo walked into the US embassy in Tegucigalpa and Hahneman surrendered.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. ==Aftermath== Hahneman was in custody but the money was not. He told authorities that he had deposited the ransom in "the Chinese Communist Bank in Hong Kong", via a mysterious Panamanian "contact".The Encyclopedia of Kidnappings by Michael Newton, Checkmark Books; 1st edition (April 1, 2002), 129 On September 11, 1972, Hahneman waived his right to a jury trialThe Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. and plead guilty to a charge of air piracy, kidnapping and extortion.The Encyclopedia of Kidnappings by Michael Newton, Checkmark Books; 1st edition (April 1, 2002), 129 He was sentenced to life imprisonment on September 29, 1972 in the US District Court in Alexandria, Va,Wikileaks cable 1973STATE088847_b and sent to the federal prison in Atlanta.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. As he left the federal building for prison, Hahneman was asked by a reporter what he'd done with the money. "None of your bloody business," he replied.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. On May 8, 1973 the FBI announced they had recovered the $303,000 ransom. In the press release they said, "Upon recovery of the money a check was made of the [[National Crime Information Center]], FBI Headquarters, Washington D.C., which determined the serial numbers tallied with the ransom money paid in connection with the hijacking."Wikileaks cable 1973STATE088847_b They provided no further details of how or where they recovered the money.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. [[Bureau of Prisons]] records show Frederick Hahneman was paroled on March 13, 1984. On August 17, 1984 he was discharged. The Bureau has no further records of him.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. ==Speculation about motives== Hahneman's arrest reignited interest in the case and his quiet Easton neighbourhood was alive with agents and reporters asking questions. His blind wife and his sons' lives were spread across the local press. Fed by the FBI's reluctance to reveal details of how and where they recovered the money, along with Hahneman's political claims while in custody and the statement from the captain, there was much speculation about Hahneman's frequent foreign trips,The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. rumours that he'd deposited the $303,000 in a communist bank,The Encyclopedia of Kidnappings by Michael Newton, Checkmark Books; 1st edition (April 1, 2002), 129 and claims that Hahneman and his cousin Roberto Martínez Ordóñez, a delegate with the Honduran mission to the [[United Nations]], were plotting a [[revolution]] in Honduras.The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. Mary Hahneman maintained that she had no contact with her husband and didn't even know he'd been released. Asked after his 1984 discharge, she said, "I still don't know why he did it. If you ever find out, will you please tell me?"The Morning Call. Frank Whelan. Sunday Call-Chronicle, 30 June 1985. ==Further reading== * https://www.wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/1973STATE088847_b.html ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Aircraft hijacking]] * [[List of aircraft hijackings]] * [[List of accidents and incidents involving the Boeing 727]] * [[D. B. Cooper]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Types of crime}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hahneman, Frederick}} [[Category:Extortion]] [[Category:Crimes]] [[Category:Hijackers]] [[Category:Aircraft hijacking]] [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:1991 deaths]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Audience response at GAIA Chamber Music Festival.jpg|thumb|300px|right| Audience response at GAIA]]
The '''GAIA Music Festival''' founded by the violinist [[Gwendolyn Masin]] is described as one of the most important festivals in [[Switzerland]].<ref>http://www.gaia-festival.com/downloads/05_GAIA_ENSUITE_2011.pdf</ref> The festival is hosted in [[Oberhofen am Thunersee|Oberhofen]] on Lake Thun, usually in the month of May. The Festival is non-profit. The Festival's director since 2015 is Jacqueline Keller. From 2010 until 2014, the Patron of the Festival was [[David Zinman]].
==History==
The GAIA Chamber Music Festival was founded in 2006, and hosted near [[Stuttgart]], where it was rewarded by two consecutive years of highly praised programmes and sold-out halls. The Festival was honoured with the Göppinger Kulturpreis<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.swp.de/goeppingen/lokales/goeppingen/Preis-fuer-herausragende-Kulturarbeit;art5583,262798 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402125242/http://www.swp.de/goeppingen/lokales/goeppingen/Preis-fuer-herausragende-Kulturarbeit%3Bart5583%2C262798 |archivedate=2 April 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref> for its outstanding impact on the cultural landscape. In 2009, the Festival made its debut in and around Thun. In 2014, the Festival was renamed to GAIA Music Festival. In 2015, the Festival made Oberhofen on the Lake of Thun its central location. [[File:Gwendolyn Masin at GAIA Festival.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Gwendolyn Masin, István Várdai, Balint Zsoldos during a concert at the 2014 edition of GAIA]]
==Musicians==
Each year, artists from all over the globe spend just over a week living and working together in Thun. The invitees, reflecting GAIA's objectives, have contributed to the world of [[arts]] in unusual and exciting ways. So far more than eighty artists have performed at the GAIA Festival.
==Artists featured ==

'''Viola:''' Alessandro D'Amico, Guy Ben-Ziony,<ref>[http://www.guybenziony.com Guy Ben-Ziony]</ref> [[Gérard Caussé]], Isabel Charisius, Jan Gruening, Ilya Hoffman, Yura Lee, Anna Lipkind, Lilli Maijala, Vladimir Mendelssohn, Natalia Tchitch, [[Lars Anders Tomter]], Mikhail Zemtsov, Dana Zemtsov
'''Cello:''' Dávid Adorján, Claudio Bohórquez, Alexander Chaushian, [[Nathalie Clein]], Thomas Demenga, Chiara Enderle, Christopher Franzius, Pavel Gomziakov, [[Frans Helmerson]], [[Louise Hopkins]], Christopher Jepson, [[Guy Johnston]], Aleksei Kiseliov, [[Dóra Kokas]], [[Gavriel Lipkind]], [[Philippe Muller]], David Pia, Timora Rosler,<ref>[http://www.timorarosler.com/ Timora Rosler]</ref> [[Martti Rousi]], Jakob Spahn, Torleif Thedéen, [[István Várdai (cellist)|István Várdai]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thestrad.com/istvan-vardai-receives-du-pre-harrell-stradivarius-cello/ |title= István Várdai receives 'Du Pré-Harrell' Stradivarius cello on extended loan |date= 13 December 2016 |publisher= The Strad |accessdate= 30 September 2017 }}</ref> Quirine Viersen

'''Harpsichord:''' Vital Julian Frey
'''Contrabass:''' Massimo Pinca
'''Flute:''' Janne Thomsen, [[Kaspar Zehnder]]
'''Clarinet:''' Reto Bieri, [[Don Li]], [[Christoffer Sundqvist]], Yevgeny Yehudin<ref>[http://www.yevgenyyehudin.com/ Yevgeny Yehudin]</ref>

'''Piano:''' Julia Bartha,<ref>[http://www.juliabartha.de/de/ Julia Bartha]</ref> Alasdair Beatson, Simon Bucher, [[Finghin Collins]], [[Peter Frankl]], Robert Kulek,<ref>[http://www.robertkulek.com/ Robert Kulek]</ref> [[Alexander Lonquich]], [[Aleksandar Madžar (musician)|Aleksandar Madzar]], [[Vincenzo Maltempo]], [[Pascal Rogé]], [[Marianna Shirinyan]], [[Cédric Pescia]], Roman Zaslavsky,<ref>[http://www.zasl.de/ Roman Zaslavsky]</ref> Bálint Zsoldos
'''[[Harp]]:''' Sarah Christ, Jana Bouškovà
'''[[Percussion]]:''' Pavel Bialiayeu, [[Andrei Pushkarev]]
'''[[Musical ensemble|Ensemble]]s:''' Ariel Quartet, Aviv Quartet, Grazioso Chamber Orchestra of the Hungarian National Philharmonic, The Lipkind Quartet, Merel Quartet, ORIGIN Ensemble (Léa Valentin (Violin), Priyanka Ravanelli (Violin), Alexina Barbe (Violin), Martin Moriarty (Viola), Patrick Moriarty (Cello)), Quatour Ernest; Tonus String Quartet, Young European Strings Chamber Orchestra, Yurodny
==Premieres==
In 2009 works by [[Don Li]], performed by the composer with Ania Losinger, Matthias Eser, and the Tonus String Quartet were introduced to the public. The arrangement of [[Johan Halvorsen]]'s "Passacaglia" - especially written for the GAIA Music Festival - received its world premiere.
In 2010, Jorge Bosso’s "Moshee" for cello and strings enjoyed its world premiere and works by [[Max Bruch]], [[Johann Sebastian Bach]], [[Pyotr Tchaikovsky]], [[Johan Halvorsen]] and [[Robert Schumann]] – including the first piano quartet by the latter – were given their debut performance in Switzerland.
Compositions or transcriptions of works by [[Kurt Atterberg]], [[Alban Berg]], [[Ernest Bloch]] and Cesar Viana were premiered in 2011.
In 2012, transcriptions of works by [[Johann Sebastian Bach]] received premieres.
2013, the fifth birthday of GAIA in Thun, saw a celebration of new works and transcriptions played for the first time by composers such as [[Luigi Boccherini]], [[Arcangelo Corelli]], [[Astor Piazzolla]], Andrei Pushkarev, [[Franz Schubert]], and by the group Yurodny.
In 2014, Bagatelle of [[Benjamin Britten]] for violin, viola and piano and works by [[Paul Juon]] received their Swiss premier.
Daniel Schnyder was Composer-in-Residence in 2015. Among the many works of his that were played during the Festival, his "Mensch Blue" had its debut performance and "Ad Parnassum" its first performance in Switzerland.
2016 saw the first inclusion of premieres of works of literature, as well as music. [[Lukas Hartmann]] wrote texts to [[Telemann]]’s "Burlesque de Quixotte"; [[Stravinsky]]’s "Suite italienne" as well as [[Mussorgsky]]’s "Pictures at an Exhibition". The latter also received its Swiss premiere in a version for string quintet and piano.<ref>http://www.srf.ch/sendungen/im-konzertsaal/gaia-musikfestival-musik-und-wort</ref> Further works to receive international premieres were by [[Camille Saint-Saëns]] and [[Manuel de Falla]], in arrangements written by [[Raymond Deane]] for [[Gwendolyn Masin]]'s ORIGIN.
The festival programme of 2017 also included several world premieres. Massimo Pinca's "The Fates" for String Quartet and Cimbalom, OLUM by Marco Antonio Perez-Ramirez, "Bartók-Impressions" (after the "Romanian Folk Dances Sz. 68" by [[Béla Bartók]]) by Miklós Lukács, as well as Maximilian Grossenbacher's "Airreel" received their world premieres. The Swiss premiere of [[Rebecca Clarke (composer)|Rebecca Clarke]]'s "Grotesque" also took place.<ref>http://www.gaia-festival.com/en/about-gaia/gaia-music-festival-oberhofen/programme-tickets/</ref><ref>http://www.bernerzeitung.ch/kultur/klassik/musikalische-reise-in-magische-sphaeren/story/15290189/</ref>
The programme of the tenth GAIA Festival saw three world premieres in 2018: "Andante für einen Oberhofer Purzelbaum" and "Bourlesque" by Thomas Fortmann and the "Hungarian-Jewish Melodies" by [[Raymond Deane]].
==Masterclasses==
Each year, internationally renowned performers and teachers coach young instrumentalists. During GAIA Masters, the most promising instrumentalist or chamber-music [[Musical ensemble|ensemble]] participating in the open [[Masterclass]]es will be chosen to return in the following year – as guest artist during the annual Music Festival.
==Artistic Director==
Artistic director and founder of the GAIA Festival is virtuoso violinist [[Gwendolyn Masin]].

:''This article only provides a detailed description of the financial market events of 2009. For the background information, causes, effects and policy responses see [[Financial crisis of 2007–08]]. For a timeline see [[Subprime crisis impact timeline]].
{{see_also|Blue Monday Crash 2009}} On the evening of January 18, the [[Denmark|Danish]] Parliament agreed to a financial package worth 100 billion [[Danish kroner]] (17.6 billion [[USD]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=Denmark agrees on 13.4-bln-euro line of credit to banks: govt|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20090118-denmark-agrees-134-bln-euro-line-credit-banks-govt-0|publisher=''[[France 24]]''|year=2009|accessdate=2009-01-19}}</ref> In response, markets panicked yet again. On January 22, the editorial board of ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'' wrote that the four largest U.S. banks "have lost half of their value since January 2."<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/2009/0122/p08s01-comv.html "Obama's First Crisis: Dud Banks", ''The Christian Science Monitor'' (January 22, 2009)]</ref>
The two-month period from January 1-February 27 represented the worst start to a year in the history of the [[S&P 500]] with a drop in value of 18.62%. By March 2, the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]] Index had dropped more than 50% from its October 2007 peak.<ref>[https://www.cnbc.com/id/29428424/site/14081545 Dow Down 50% Since Peak, Major Indices Approach New Lows], 27 Feb 2009, CNBC.com</ref> The decline has been compared to that of the 1929 Great Depression, which was 53% between September 1929 and March 1931.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/03/business/worldbusiness/03markets.html Steep Market Drops Highlight Despair Over Rescue Efforts]</ref>
On March 6, the Bank of England announced up to 150 billion pounds of [[quantitative easing]], increasing the risk of inflation.<ref>[http://www.financialpost.com/careers/story.html?id=1356326 BoE cuts rate to 0.5%, embraces 'quantitative easing']. [[Financial Post]].</ref>
In March 2009, Blackstone Group CEO [[Stephen Schwarzman]] said that up to 45% of global wealth had been destroyed by the global financial crisis.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/ousiv/idUSTRE52966Z20090310 45 percent of world's wealth destroyed: Blackstone CEO]. Reuters. March 10, 2009.</ref>
By March 9, 2009, the Dow had fallen to 6440, a percentage decline exceeding the pace of the market's fall during the [[Great Depression]] and a level which the index had last seen in 1996. On March 10, 2009, a countertrend [[bear market rally]] began, taking the Dow up to 8500 by May 6, 2009. Financial stocks were up more than 150% during this rally. By May 9, financial stocks had rallied more than 150% in just over two months.
On June 22 the [[World Bank]] projected that the global production for 2009 would fall by 2.9%, the first decline since the second world war.<ref>[http://www.worldbank.org/html/extdr/financialcrisis/ World Banks projection of June 22]</ref>

Produced by [[Craig Zadan]] and [[Neil Meron]], and hosted by [[Darren Criss]], it is a performance of a new adaptation of the 2002 Broadway musical ''[[Hairspray (musical)|Hairspray]]''. ==Premise== ''Hairspray Live!'' takes place in 1962 Baltimore. Teenager Tracy Turnblad’s dream is to dance on The Corny Collins Show, a local TV program. When, against all odds, Tracy wins a role on the show, she becomes a celebrity overnight and meets a colorful array of characters, including Link, the resident dreamboat; Amber, the ambitious mean girl; Seaweed, an African-American boy she meets in detention; and his mother, Motormouth Maybelle, owner of a local record store. Tracy’s mother is the indomitable Edna Turnblad, and she eventually encourages Tracy on her campaign to integrate the all-white Corny Collins Show."{{cite web|last1=Petski|first1=Denise|title=Jennifer Hudson & Harvey Fierstein To Topline NBC’s ‘Hairspray Live’|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/jennifer-hudson-harvey-fierstein-nbc-hairspray-live-1201743160/|website=Deadline|accessdate=March 31, 2018|date=April 25, 2016}} ==Cast and characters== '''Main Cast'''Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/article/billy-eichner-added-to-hairspray-live-full-cast-revealed "Billy Eichner Added to 'Hairspray Live!' — Full Cast Revealed"] Playbill, September 21, 2016 {{div col}} * Maddie Baillio as Tracy Turnblad * [[Harvey Fierstein]] as Edna Turnblad * [[Dove Cameron]] as Amber Von Tussle * [[Kristin Chenoweth]] as Velma Von Tussle * [[Ariana Grande]] as Penny Pingleton * [[Garrett Clayton]] as Link Larkin * [[Ephraim Sykes]] as Seaweed J. Stubbs * [[Jennifer Hudson]] as Motormouth Maybelle * [[Martin Short]] as Wilbur Turnblad * [[Derek Hough]] as Corny Collins * Shahadi Wright Joseph as Inez Stubbs {{div col end}} '''Minor Roles''' {{div col}} * [[Andrea Martin]] as Prudy PingletonKennedy,Mark. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/tv/comedian-andrea-martin-joins-hairspray-live-cast/2016/08/18/af05a944-656a-11e6-b4d8-33e931b5a26d_story.html "Comedian Andrea Martin joins ‘Hairspray Live!’ cast"] ''The Washington Post'', August 18, 2016 * [[Paul C. Vogt|Paul Vogt]] as Mr. Harriman F. Spritzer * [[Billy Eichner]] as Rob BarkerSnetiker, Marc. [http://www.ew.com/article/2016/09/21/billy-eichner-hairspray-live "Billy Eichner Joins 'Hairspray Live' "] ew.com, September 21, 2016 * [[Sean Hayes (actor)|Sean Hayes]] as Mr. Pinky * [[Rosie O'Donnell]] as The Gym Teacher Holloway, Stanley. Bell as Duane * Joanna Jones as Genie Mae * Tiana Okoye as Lorraine * Amos Oliver III as Thad * Re'sean Pates as Jackie * Rhon Saunders as Gilbert {{div col end}} '''Various Ensemble''' * Zack Everhart, Annie Gratton, Thomasina Gross, Allie Meixner, Eliotte Nicole, Tyler Parks, Andrew Pirozzi, Joy Marie Thomas, Keenan Washington, and Jason Williams '''Cameos''' * [[Ricki Lake]] (Tracy Turnblad in the original 1988 film) and [[Marissa Jaret Winokur]] (original Tracy Turnblad on Broadway) as Mr. Pinky's Girls[http://perezhilton.com/2016-11-16-hairspray-live-marissa-jaret-winokur-ricki-lake-maddie-baillio-cast-cameo-quotes#.WDiiIKIrIy4 " 'Hairspray Live' Marissa Jaret Winokur Ricki Lake Maddie Baillio Cast Cameo Quotes#.WDiiIKIrIy4] perezhilton.com, November 12, 2016 ==Musical numbers== The musical numbers from the track list of the soundtrack.[https://www.amazon.com/Hairspray-Original-Soundtrack-Television-Event/dp/B01M7SRGB2# "Hairspray LIVE! Original Soundtrack of the NBC Television Event"] Amazon, Retrieved October 24, 2016 {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ;Act I * "[[Good Morning Baltimore]]" – Tracy and Ensemble * "The Nicest Kids in Town" – Corny and Council Members * "Mama, I'm a Big Girl Now" – Edna, Tracy, Prudy, Penny, Velma, Amber, and Ensemble * "[[I Can Hear the Bells]]" – Tracy and Ensemble * "[[(The Legend of) Miss Baltimore Crabs]]" – Velma and Council Members * "[[Ladies' Choice (Hairspray song)|Ladies' Choice]]" - Corny * "It Takes Two" – Link and Tracy * "Velma's Revenge" - Velma * "[[Welcome to the 60's]]" – Tracy, Edna, The Dynamites, Mr. Pinky, and Ensemble * "[[Run and Tell That|Run and Tell That!]]" – Seaweed, Little Inez, and Ensemble * "[[Big, Blonde and Beautiful]]" – Motormouth and Ensemble {{col-break}} ;Act II * "(You're) Timeless to Me" – Edna and Wilbur * "Good Morning Baltimore (Reprise)" – Tracy * "[[Without Love (Hairspray song)|Without Love]]" – Tracy, Link, Penny, Seaweed, and Ensemble * "[[I Know Where I've Been]]" – Motormouth * "(It's) Hairspray" – Corny and Council Members * "Cooties" – Amber and Council Members * "[[You Can't Stop the Beat]]" – Tracy, Link, Penny, Seaweed, Edna, Wilbur, Motormouth, Velma, Amber, and Company ;Encore * "Come So Far (Got So Far to Go)" – Ariana Grande, Jennifer Hudson, and Company {{col-end}} ==Production== ===Development=== ''Hairspray Live!'' served as NBC's fourth entry in its series of made-for-TV musical telecasts, behind ''[[The Wiz Live!]]'', ''[[Peter Pan Live!]]'', and ''[[The Sound of Music Live!]]''. As with its predecessors, it was executive produced by [[Craig Zadan]] and [[Neil Meron]]. The project was revealed by NBC's entertainment head [[Bob Greenblatt]] during a [[Television Critics Association]] press tour in January 2016. In response to early reports that NBC was considering a live version of ''[[The Music Man]]'', ''[[West Side Story]]'' or ''[[Cinderella (musical)|Rodgers and Hammerstein's Cinderella]]'', Greenblatt stated that "people have been saying to me since ''The Wiz'', 'Do this show, do that show.' I've heard obscure titles and famous titles. Not everything's going to be a big name to the whole audience. I don’t think there's an infinite number of these that can be done. But we're still doing it." He explained that the production would not try to emulate the [[Hairspray (2007 film)|2007 film]] (also produced by Zadan and Meron),{{cite news|title=Craig Zadan and Neil Meron Signed to Produce New Line Cinema's Musical Film Version of Hairspray |publisher=[[Time Warner]] |date=2004-11-29 |url=http://www.timewarner.com/corp/newsroom/pr/0,20812,832538,00.html |accessdate=2007-08-20}} but that he would have been thrilled if [[John Travolta]] reprised his role in it.{{cite web|last1=Abrams|first1=Natalie|title=Hairspray live musical coming to NBC in December|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=January 13, 2016|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/01/13/hairspray-nbc-live-musical|accessdate=January 14, 2016}} [[Kenny Leon]] returned in his role as director from ''The Wiz'', and was joined by Alex Rudzinski—who co-directed ''[[Grease: Live]]'' for Fox.{{cite web|title=Hairspray Live Is Figuring Out How to Perfect the Live Musical|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2016/12/hairspray-live-nbc-ariana-grande-jennifer-hudson-director-interview|website=Vanity Fair|accessdate=8 December 2016}} The musical was adapted for television by [[Harvey Fierstein]] from the original book by [[Mark O'Donnell]] and [[Thomas Meehan (writer)|Thomas Meehan]]. [[Jerry Mitchell]], the choreographer of the Broadway version of ''Hairspray'', was also involved with the adaptation.Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/kenny-leon-jerry-mitchell-and-harvey-fierstein-will-bring-hairspray-to-life-for-nbc-broadcast-date-set-387509# "Kenny Leon, Jerry Mitchell and Harvey Fierstein Will Bring 'Hairspray' to Life for NBC; Broadcast Date Set "], Playbill, February 18, 2016 In contrast to NBC's previous musicals, ''Hairspray Live!'' was produced from the [[Universal Studios]] [[Universal Studios Lot|backlot]]; Greenblatt explained that a "fair amount" of the show would be staged in outdoor settings, and thus "have a real exuberance in the open air." Additionally, live audiences were integrated into relevant scenes as extras on-stage, such as bystanders in Baltimore, and as the studio audience of ''The Corny Collins Show''.Clement, Olivia. [http://www.playbill.com/article/exclusive-hairspray-live-to-feature-live-audience-and-new-songs# "Exclusive: 'Hairspray Live! 'to Feature Live Audience and New Songs"], Playbill, April 26, 2016 Two numbers written for the 2007 film, "Ladies' Choice” and "Come So Far (Got So Far to Go)", were incorporated into the production. "The Big Dollhouse", from the Broadway show, was cut, while "The New Girl In Town", written for the stage show but cut and only used in the film, was not added.Gioia, Michael. [http://www.playbill.com/article/musical-numbers-for-hairspray-live-revealed# "Musical Numbers for 'Hairspray Live!' Revealed"], Playbill, November 4, 2016 (An instrumental version of the song is, however, heard very briefly as a bit of background music.) ===Casting=== In addition to adapting the book, Fierstein reprised his performance of Edna Turnblad from the Broadway musical; Greenblatt felt that his performance of Edna was "iconic", and that his involvement with ''Hairspray Live!'' made it "come full circle". NBC cast the lead role of Tracy Turnblad through an open call in New York City, hoping to repeat the "phenomenal discovery" of Shanice Williams for ''The Wiz''. The role went to college sophomore Maddie Baillio, as her first professional role.{{cite web|title=Hairspray Live! casts newcomer Maddie Baillio as Tracy Turnblad|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/06/07/hairspray-live-nbc-maddie-baillio-tracy-turnblad|website=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=8 December 2016}} In November 2016, it was announced that [[Ricki Lake]] and [[Marissa Jaret Winokur]] (who portrayed Tracy Turnblad in the [[Hairspray (1988 film)|1988 film]] and the Broadway version respectively) would make cameo appearances;Gioia, Michael. [http://www.playbill.com/article/ariana-grande-and-jennifer-hudson-will-duet-on-hairspray-live-finale# "Ariana Grande and Jennifer Hudson Will Duet on 'Hairspray Live!' Finale"] Playbill, November 16, 2016 Winokur and Lake appeared as employees of Mr. Pinky's boutique. [[Darren Criss]] served as an on-air host, hosting a half-hour ''Countdown to Hairspray Live!'' show on NBC with Kristin Chenoweth and Sean Hayes, as well as behind-the-scenes reports throughout the live broadcast.{{cite web|title=Odds & Ends: Darren Criss Hops on the Hairspray Live! Beat, Idina Menzel & Jennifer Nettles Belt for Baby Jesus & More|url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/186889/odds-ends-darren-criss-hops-on-the-hairspray-live-beat-idina-menzel-jennifer-nettles-belt-for-baby-jesus-more/|website=Broadway.com|accessdate=8 December 2016}}{{cite web|title=Kristin Chenoweth & Sean Hayes to Co-Host Hairspray Live! Pre-Show|url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/186761/kristin-chenoweth-sean-hayes-to-co-host-hairspray-live-pre-show/|website=Broadway.com|accessdate=8 December 2016}} ===Marketing=== [[Oreo]], [[Reddi-wip]], and [[Toyota]] broadcast live, themed commercials during ''Hairspray Live!''; Oreo's ad featured the character of Corny Collins, Reddi-wip's ad featured a [[milkman]] character (Evan Strand) backstage and performing a dance number, while Toyota's ad featured a vintage [[Toyota Corolla]] and a current model in celebration of the vehicle's 50th anniversary.{{cite web|title=Reddi-Wip is Camera-Ready in 'Hairspray Live!': It's Last Night's New Ads|url=http://adage.com/article/media/reddi-wip-camera-ready-hairspray-live-spot/307086/|website=Advertising Age|accessdate=11 December 2016}}{{cite web|title=Live Commercials to Air During NBCU’s ‘Hairspray'|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/currency/live-commercials-air-during-nbcu-s-hairspray/161634|website=Broadcasting & Cable|accessdate=9 December 2016}} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the special holds a 79% rating based on 24 reviews, with an [[Weighted mean|average]] of 8.2/10. The site's consensus states: "''Hairspray Live!'' shimmers with outstanding performances, an engaging story, and songs that let its stars shine."{{cite web | url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/hairspray_live | title=Hairspray Live! (2016) | work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher=[[Fandango Media]] | accessdate=March 7, 2018}} It has a score of 66 from 14 critics on [[Metacritic]], indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/hairspray-live! |title=Hairspray Live! Reviews | work=[[Metacritic]] | publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate=March 7, 2018}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' reviewer wrote: "NBC lassoed some talented performers with fine singing voices but sacrificed cohesion by cramming the evening with too much interstitial fluff.... Only Jennifer Hudson, who played Motormouth Maybelle, found the real strength of this Tony-winning musical, delivering a knockout rendition of 'I Know Where I've Been'..." He noted that Baillio "did pretty well, though no novice is going to compete with voices like those of Ms. Hudson and Kristin Chenoweth..."Genzlinger, Neil. [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/08/arts/television/review-hairspray-live.html?rref=collection/sectioncollection/arts "Review: ‘Hairspray Live!’ Had Power Voices but Still Lacked Power"] ''The New York Times'', December 8, 2016 The ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reviewer wrote that it "took a few musical numbers to settle into a rhythm. But once it did (the energy seemed to kick in with "Welcome to the ‘60s") the musical easily became the best NBC has attempted. It's hard to imagine better casting for the production. Jennifer Hudson stole the show... Ariana Grande, certifiable pop star, came away as the show's MVP, acting as both reliably overlook-able sidekick and, once the situation required it, showstopping diva. Harvey Fierstein was predictably great... Martin Short... found the right profile for himself as Wilbur."Saraiya, Sonia. [https://variety.com/2016/tv/reviews/tv-review-hairspray-live-jennifer-hudson-ariana-grande-1201936567/ "TV Review: ‘Hairspray Live!’"] ''Variety'', December 8, 2016 The TV Ratings Guide reviewer wrote that the production "was truly a great experience through and through." They praised the entire cast, stating "the casting was just top notch", and praised Grande and Hudson in particular. They named 'You Can't Stop the Beat' the best musical moment of the night and stated that "they really knocked it out of the park." They stated that "NBC really put together something amazing here." Bunch, Rebecca. [http://www.tvratingsguide.com/2016/12/hairspray-live-spoiler-free-review-nbcs.html "Hairspray Live! (Spoiler-Free) Review: NBC's Live Musical is A-mazing’"] ''The TV Ratings Guide'', December 8, 2016 [[The A.V. Club]]'s reviewer wrote that "As a piece of social commentary, tonight’s production of Hairspray Live! was just about flawless." They stated that Dove Cameron and Ephraim Sykes were "consistently fun to watch", and that Chenoweth and Hudson "were the biggest scene-stealers." They said that Fierstein, Short, and Martin "were all wonderful as well." They rated the telecast a B+.Siede, Caroline. [http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/exuberant-hairspray-live-offers-light-darkness-247101 "An exuberant Hairspray Live! offers a light in the darkness’"] ''The A.V. Club'', December 8, 2016 ===Viewership=== ''Hairspray Live!'' was seen by 9.05 million viewers, with a ratings share of 2.3 in the 18–49 demographic, and a 5.9 overnight household rating. It was the most-viewed program of the night, with numbers on par with those of ''Peter Pan''.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvratingsguide.com/2016/12/tv-ratings-12716-hairspray-live-is-not.html|title= TV Ratings 12/7/16: Hairspray Live! Is Not Huge, but it still brings down ABC's Ratings (UPDATED)|last=Bunch|first=Rebecca|date=December 8, 2016|work=The TV Ratings Guide|accessdate=December 8, 2016}}Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/article/hairspray-live-ratings-down-from-last-seasons-the-wiz# " 'Hairspray Live!' Ratings Down from Last Season’s 'The Wiz' "] Playbill, December 8, 2016 An encore presentation, which aired on December 27, was seen by 2.5 million viewers.TV News Desk. [http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Encore-Telecast-of-NBCs-HAIRSPRAY-LIVE-Delivers-25-Million-Viewers-Overall-20161227 "Encore Telecast of NBC's HAIRSPRAY LIVE! Delivers 2.5 Million Viewers Overall"] Broadway World, December 27, 2016 ===Awards and nominations=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! width="25%"| Award ! width="35%"| Category ! width="30%"| Nominated artist/work ! width="10%"| Result ! scope="col" class="unsortable" width="4%"| {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- | [[Art Directors Guild Awards 2016|Art Directors Guild Awards]] | Awards or Event Special | [[Derek McLane]] | {{nom}} |align="center"| {{cite web|last1=Hipes|first1=Patrick|title=Art Directors Guild Awards Nominations: ‘Rogue One’, ‘Game Of Thrones’ & More|url=http://deadline.com/2017/01/art-directors-guild-nominations-2017-full-list-1201878962/|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=5 January 2017}} |- | [[69th Directors Guild of America Awards|Directors Guild of America Awards]] | [[Directors Guild of America Award for Outstanding Directing – Miniseries or TV Film|Outstanding Directing – Miniseries or TV Film]] | [[Kenny Leon]] and Alex Rudzinski | {{nom}} | align="center" | {{cite web|last1=Hipes|first1=Patrick|title=DGA TV Awards Nominations: ‘Stranger Things’, ‘Westworld’ & ‘Atlanta’ On List; Docus Include ‘OJ: Made In America’|url=http://deadline.com/2017/01/2017-dga-tv-awards-nominees-directors-guild-nominations-1201883327/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=11 January 2017}} |- | Make-Up Artists and Hair Stylist Guild Awards | Television Mini-Series or Movie Made for Television - {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox recurring event |name=HowTheLightGetsIn Festival |image=HowTheLightGetsIn 2016.jpg |website=http://howthelightgetsin.org |genre=[[Philosophy]], [[music]]|caption=HowTheLightGetsIn Festival 2016}} '''HowTheLightGetsIn Festival''' is the world's largest philosophy and music festival, hosted by the [[Institute of Art and Ideas]]. It aims "to get philosophy out of the academy and into people's lives"<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/may/22/hay-festival-enlightenment-fringe</ref> by bringing together philosophers, writers, academics, comedians and musicians for a festival of debate, talks, music, workshops, and late night parties.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newstatesman.com/culture/2013/05/hilary-lawson-error-philosophy-and-ted|title=Hilary Lawson on error, philosophy and TED: "It’s really a business conference organisation"|website=www.newstatesman.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref>
Speakers at the festival have included [[Ed Miliband|Ed Milliband]], [[Noam Chomsky]], [[Kimberlé Williams Crenshaw|Kimberle Crenshaw]], [[Philip Pullman]], [[Diane Abbott]], [[Robert Skidelsky]], [[Stanley Fish]], [[Steven Pinker]], [[Brian Eno]] and [[Laurie Penny]], among others. Held at the same time as the [[Hay Festival]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/may/22/hay-festival-enlightenment-fringe|title=Enlightenment comes to the Hay festival|last=Pauli|first=Michelle|date=2009-05-22|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-10-11|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> and based in a riverside setting by the banks of the [[River Wye]], HowTheLightGetsIn attracts a footfall of over 30,000 each year.
In September 2018, HowTheLightGetsIn hosted its first ever [https://www.howthelightgetsin.org/london London festival] on the grounds of [[Kenwood House]] in [[Hampstead Heath]].
== 2018 London, 'Tribal Truths and New Wisdoms' == From 22–23 September 2018, HowTheLightGetsIn will be hosting its first ever [https://howthelightgetsin.org/london/ London festival] on the grounds of [[Kenwood House]] in [[Hampstead Heath]].
The festival theme is Tribal Truths and New Wisdoms, seeking to 'challenge current tribal truths and exploring new alternatives that might enable us to chart a better course'. Speakers will include neuroscientist [[Steven Pinker]], philosopher and author [[Rebecca Goldstein]], Banksy's former agent [[Steve Lazarides]], novelist [[Deborah Levy]], Turner Prize architect Paloma Strelitz, long-time Hawking collaborator [[Roger Penrose]], Nobel Prize winning physicist [[Gerard 't Hooft|Gerald 'T Hooft]], and LGBQT+ activist [[Peter Tatchell]].
== 2018 'Darkness, Authority and Dreams' == After taking a fallow year in 2017, the 2018 May festival took place from 25–28 May 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hay.htlgi.iai.tv/|title=HowTheLightGetsIn 2018: Hay-on-Wye Philosophy and Music Festival|date=2017-05-18|work=HowTheLightGetsIn 2018: Hay-on-Wye Philosophy Festival - The World's Largest Philosophy and Music Festival|access-date=2017-10-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
Speakers included political theorist [[Noam Chomsky]], psychiatrist and former Government Drugs Adviser [[David Nutt]], linguist [[John McWhorter]], Shadow Home Secretary [[Diane Abbott]], former Archbishop of Canterbury [[Rowan Williams]], economist [[Deirdre McCloskey]].<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/how-the-light-gets-in-festival-review-wales-hay-on-wye-culture-philosophy-politics-a8383761.html</ref> The music line-up featured [[Scissor Sisters]]' [[Ana Matronic]], [[Hot Chip]], [[The Correspondents (band)|The Correspondents]], [[Nerina Pallot]] and [[Laura Wright (singer)|Laura Wright]].
== 2016 'The Known, the Strange, and the New'<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/digitaliberties/idea-of-festival-how-light-gets-in|title=The idea of a festival: How The Light Gets In|date=2016-05-27|website=openDemocracy|language=en|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref> == [[File:Natalie Bennett and Patricia Lewis at HowTheLightGetsIn 2016.jpg|thumb|[[Natalie Bennett]] and Patricia Lewis at HowTheLightGetsIn 2016]] The 2016 festival took place from 26 May to 5 June.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/digitaliberties/idea-of-festival-how-light-gets-in|title=Open Democracy|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2017-10-11|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> Speakers were to include [[Natalie Bennett]], [[Owen Jones (writer)|Owen Jones]], [[Ken Livingstone]], Bernard Carr,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/bernard-carr/time-and-consciousness_b_9855418.html|title=Time and Consciousness|website=HuffPost UK|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref> Kwasi Karteng<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/kwasi-kwarteng/uk-economy-inequality_b_10023726.html|title=Wealth, Justice and Prosperity|website=HuffPost UK|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref> and [[Roger Scruton]]. The music lineup featured [[Ghostpoet]], [[Fairport Convention]], [[Gilles Peterson]], [[C Duncan]], [[Eska (singer)|Eska]], and [[Tom Robinson]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://howthelightgetsin.iai.tv|title = HowTheLightGetsIn 2016|website = howthelightgetsin.iai.tv|access-date = 2016-03-02}}</ref>
==2015 'Fantasy and Reality'==
Described as "Europe's answer to TED",<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.totalpolitics.com/articles/news/error-lies-and-adventure-politics-video|title='Error, lies and adventure': Politics on video|date=2012-12-06|work=TotalPolitics.com|access-date=2017-10-11|language=en}}</ref> the festival for 2015 took place from 21 to 31 May 2015<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.anothermag.com/design-living/7462/what-you-should-do-at-hay-festival-how-the-light-gets-in|title=What You Should Do at Hay Festival & How The Light Gets In|last=AnOther|work=AnOther|access-date=2017-10-11|language=en}}</ref> and included performances and talks from [[Simon Blackburn]], [[Mike Skinner (musician)|Mike Skinner]], [[George Galloway]], [[Natalie Bennett]], [[Lawrence Krauss]], [[Michael Howard]], [[Lianne La Havas]], Yasmin Alibhai-Brown<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/yasmin-alibhaibrown/whose-england_b_7170530.html|title=Whose England?|website=HuffPost UK|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref> and [[Rae Morris]] among others. As part of the festival, the [[New College of the Humanities]] presented the IAI School. Aimed at 16- to 18-year-olds, the IAI School explored topics such as Free Will and Politics, Sex Ethics and Morality.
==2014 'Heresy, Truth and the Future'==
HTLGI 2014 attracted a footfall of over 35,000 across 450 events.<ref>http://www.thefestivalcalendar.co.uk/festivals/How_The_Light_Gets_In_2015</ref> Speakers and performers included [[Roger Penrose]], [[Brooke Magnanti]], [[Bruce Parry]], [[Doon Mackichan]], [[Cory Doctorow]], [[Owen Jones (writer)|Owen Jones]], [[David Nutt]], [[Molotov Jukebox]], [[Moulettes]], [[Natalie Bennett]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/natalie-bennett/education-competition_b_5420235.html|title=Let's Get Heretical on Education: Competition Has Failed|website=HuffPost UK|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref> and [[Mr Scruff]].
==2012 'Uncharted Territory: Progress for a New Era'==
The 2012 festival<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/06/07/how-the-light-gets-in-2012-video_n_1577150.html|title=A Summer Festival ...Of Philosophy?!|date=2012-06-07|work=HuffPost UK|access-date=2017-10-11|language=en-GB}}</ref> sought to question existing notions of progress through an exploration of issues surrounding political, economic and ethical advance in the West. By acknowledging the uncertainty of the future and its values, do we need to establish new ideas of progress or is such a suggestion inherently flawed?
It was held in [[Hay-on-Wye]] and ran between 31 May and 10 June 2012. The festival staged almost five hundred sessions across the site’s five venues.
Amongst the speakers on the festival’s programme were musician [[Brian Eno]], founder of Glastonbury festival [[Michael Eavis]], literary theorist and critic [[Terry Eagleton]] and independent scientist and inventor [[James Lovelock]]. Musical highlights included performances from [[Charlotte Church]], [[Emmy the Great]], and [[Jeffrey Lewis]] and the Junkyard, as well as a twelve-hour painting marathon from artist [[Stella Vine]] to accompany a performance by alternative rock band [[The Chapman Family]].
London's Open Gallery, an institution dedicated to the medium of [[video painting]], also staged a series works by filmmaker Roz Mortimer entitled, ‘Sites of Memory’.
==2011 ‘New Gods: Icons and Ideas in a Changed World’== [[file:HowTheLightGetsIn.jpg|thumb|HowTheLightGetsIn Festival 2011]]
The 2011 festival questioned whether the great narratives that have built and sustained the West are under threat and, if so, what are the new gods that will replace them?
Speakers at the festival included critical theorist [[Leela Gandhi]], Times columnist [[David Aaronovitch]], poet [[Simon Armitage]], New Statesman culture editor [[Jonathan Derbyshire]] and screenwriter [[Jez Butterworth]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/news/how-did-they-get-in-hay-festivals-success-spawns-its-own-fringe-2292894.html|title=How did they get in? Hay Festival's success spawns its own fringe|date=2011-06-04|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-10-11|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Cultural highlights ranged from [[Ghostpoet]], [[Mount Kimbie]] and [[The Correspondents (band)|The Correspondents]], to comedy and the screening of documentaries from around the world with [[BBC Four]].
==2010 ‘Being Human’==
The 2010 festival posed the questions: What is it to be alive? What is essential to our humanity and what is peripheral? What is truly important in life?
Author of Politics of Fear [[Frank Furedi]], filmmaker [[David Bond (filmmaker)|David Bond]], author [[Philip Pullman]] and Labour politician [[Jon Cruddas]], were amongst the speakers on the line up.
The Open Gallery explored the boundary between the human and the natural. [[The Wellcome Trust]]<ref>http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/</ref> Identity Project presented an exhibition and two days of events on the topic of Identity. Notably, The School of Life<ref>http://www.theschooloflife.com/</ref> hosted a series of philosophy breakfasts with leading thinkers over the 10-day festival.
Radio 1’s [[Huw Stephens]] and John Rostron, the duo behind the Sŵn Festival, curated a night of cutting-edge music, which was accompanied by live performances from [[Johnny Flynn (musician)|Johnny Flynn]], Cate le Bon and Radio 1’s [[Bethan Elfyn]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/wales/entries/4cedc3be-34d0-3f69-bc3c-1b1bba08addf|title=Review: How The Light Gets In festival, Hay on Wye|date=2010-06-09|website=Wales|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref>

(2000) | this_tour = '''Last Encore Tour'''
(2010-11) | next_tour = | Misc = }} The '''Last Encore Tour'''{{cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/saginaw/index.ssf/2010/06/the_judds_include_mount_pleasa.html |title=The Judds include Mount Pleasant's Soaring Eagle in The Last Encore tour |author=White, Sue |date= |work=[[The Saginaw News]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z1g1nN89?url=http://www.mlive.com/news/saginaw/index.ssf/2010/06/the_judds_include_mount_pleasa.html |archivedate=28 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} is a concert tour by [[People of the United States|American]] recording artist, [[The Judds]]. The tour is the duo's first tour in 10 years, the last being the "Power to Change Tour" in 2000. The duo states this is the final farewell tour for the group. The tour began November 2010 and ended in December. In 2011, the duo announced a second United States leg for the summer of 2011. The tour predominately visited the United States. The duo stated that the purpose for the tour was to reconnect with their fans. The tour's title was suggested by fans on Wynonna's website, as the duo had to come up with a name. Naomi Judd remarked "[I] was going to suggest 'The Cougar Tour'."{{cite web|url=http://www.news10.net/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=83404&catid=37 |title=The Judds: The last encore tour |author=Hamataka, Constance |date=11 June 2010 |work=[[KXTV]] |publisher=[[Gannett Company]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z1jTE4Fg?url=http://www.news10.net/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=83404 |archivedate=28 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} They were joined on tour by the [[Palmetto State Quartet]].{{cite web|url=http://qctimes.com/entertainment/music/article_6ec61290-f42a-11df-99c6-001cc4c002e0.html |title=‘Last Encore’ allows Judds to reconnect, say farewell to fans |author=Burke, David |date=21 November 2010 |work=[[Quad-City Times]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z1n3q0qr?url=http://qctimes.com/entertainment/music/article_6ec61290-f42a-11df-99c6-001cc4c002e0.html |archivedate=28 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Background== In 2009, the duo performed together for the first time in nine years the 2009 [[CMA Music Festival]] at [[LP Field]].{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2009-06-14-cma-wrapup_N.htm |title=CMA Festival hits all the right notes |author=Hendrickson, Lucas |date=15 June 2009 |work=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z1ed9QsY?url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2009-06-14-cma-wrapup_N.htm |archivedate=28 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The performance spaced media outlets within the country music scene to hint to a reunion of the duo to be as early as 2010. During the summer of 2009, the duo made rare concert appearances together, including a stop at the [[Mohegan Sun Arena]] in [[Montville, Connecticut|Uncasville, Connecticut]].{{cite web|url=http://www.norwichbulletin.com/entertainment/x931213843/Jimmy-Lane-Judds-reuniting-for-rare-show-at-Mohegan-Sun#axzz1NgDDD4Ue |title=Jimmy Lane: Judds reuniting for rare show at Mohegan Sun |author=Lane, Jimmy |date=1 July 2009 |work=[[Norwich Bulletin]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z1fJFF6Q?url=http://www.norwichbulletin.com/entertainment/x931213843/Jimmy-Lane-Judds-reuniting-for-rare-show-at-Mohegan-Sun |archivedate=28 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The duo also opened a museum in [[Franklin, Tennessee]], to commemorate their 25 years in country music.{{cite web|url=http://www.pollstar.com/blogs/news/archive/2009/06/12/672433.aspx |title=The Judds Museum Opens |author=Pittman, Sarah Marie |date=12 June 2009 |work=Pollstar |agency=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z1fd6xe5?url=http://www.pollstar.com/blogs/news/archive/2009/06/12/672433.aspx |archivedate=28 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In the course of an interview for ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', [[Wynonna Judd]] stated the duo was open to perform on tour and recording new music in 2010. She continued, "It's 2010. It's been 25 years. It's take your mother to work year. It just feels like it's the right time".{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/266721/wynonna-naomi-reuniting-the-judds-in-2010 |title=Wynonna, Naomi Reuniting The Judds In 2010 |author=Graff, Gary |date=13 November 2009 |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z1dR3Eb7?url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/the-judds/2390 |archivedate=28 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Judd wanted to bring her mother, [[Naomi Judd]] along for her annual "Classic Christmas Tour", however Naomi declined. The tour was officially announced in February 2010.{{cite news |title=The Judds to reunite for tour |author= |url=http://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/Music/2010/02/07/The-Judds-to-reunite-for-tour/UPI-95261265560687|agency=[[United Press International]] |date=7 February 2010 |accessdate=26 May 2011}} The duo would later headline the 2010 CMA Music Festival. At the press conference following the event, the duo remark the audience response for their 2009 show encouraged them to go on this trek one final time.{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1641286/the-judds-welcome-crowds-to-cma-music-festival-announce-tour-dates.jhtml |title=The Judds Welcome Crowds to CMA Music Festival, Announce Tour Dates |author=Shelburne, Craig |date=10 June 2010 |work=[[Country Music Television|CMT News]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z1hPqRZy?url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1641286/the-judds-welcome-crowds-to-cma-music-festival-announce-tour-dates.jhtml |archivedate=28 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Naomi stated her woman's intuition have her the courage to get back on stage and concert promoters assured her there was a demand for the tour. Also, the duo announced their first reality television series entitled ''The Judds'', to air on [[Oprah Winfrey Network (U.S. TV channel)|OWN: Oprah Winfrey Network]]. The show will follow the duo's tour, while showing their mother-daughter relationship in both a public and private scope.{{cite web |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2010-11-01/entertainment/27079865_1_carson-kressley-o-neals-show |title=Oprah Winfrey's OWN network announces 'The Judds,' Tatum, Ryan O'Neal series, Carson Kressley show |author=Huff, Richard |date=1 November 2010 |work= [[New York Daily News]] |accessdate=27 May 2011}} To promote the tour, the duo appeared on ''[[Larry King Live]]'', ''[[The Early Show]]'', ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'', ''[[Weekend Edition]]'' and ''[[Crook & Chase]]'', while gracing the covers of ''[[Country Weekly]]'' and ''[[People (magazine)|People: Country Special]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/02/03/earlyshow/saturday/main6171092.shtml |title=Judds Reuniting for One More Tour |author= |date=6 February 2010 |work=[[CBS News]] |accessdate=27 May 2011}} To introduce the tour, the duo stated:
"[Wynonna] This tour gives me a chance to enjoy where Mom and I are in our relationship. I look forward to celebrating our personal and professional journey…together. [Naomi] There is nothing like music and laughter to connect people. How I've missed that encounter with the very ones who've allowed us that awesome privilege! I'm counting the days till I can be back on my bus, visiting their towns."{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/blog/rootstootshoots/entry.asp?xid=623 |title=Is this really it for The Judds? |author=Remz, Jeremy |date=11 June 2010 |work=[[Country Standard Time]] |publisher= |accessdate=27 May 2011}}

Jon Bream (''[[Star Tribune]]'') notes despite Wynonna's vocal problems, the duo were still able to pull off a fantastic show at the sold out Mystic Showroom. He elaborates, "As Wynonna handed lead vocal chores to her backup singers, it seemed appropriate—for more reasons than one—that the Judds ended their Last Encore show with ''Silent Night''".{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/templates/Print_This_Story?sid=111091404 |title=High notes out of reach, Judds still touched hearts |author=Bream, Jon |date=1 December 2010 |work=Star Tribune |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z27JRFcj?url=http://www.startribune.com/templates/Print_This_Story?sid=111091404 |archivedate=29 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Gary Budzak (''[[The Columbus Dispatch]]'') called the evening a success for the Columbus audience. He states, "On more than 30 songs that spanned a quarter-century, The Judds have proved they still had the wherewithal to charm the crowd, whether it was Wynonna hugging a 4-year-old girl on stage; or Naomi kissing her husband, bass singer Larry Strickland, on a cover of ''Don't Be Cruel''".{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.com/live/content/arts/stories/2010/12/03/review_judds.html |title=Another successful 'encore' |author=Budzak, Gary |date=3 December 2010 |work=[[The Columbus Dispatch]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z27YOztC?url=http://www.dispatch.com/live/content/arts/stories/2010/12/03/review_judds.html |archivedate=29 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The praise continued with Kevin C. Johnson (''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]''). The concert at the Family Arena served as a fitting finale for the duo. He explains, "This is The Last Encore tour, positioned as the final go-round for country music's most successful mother-daughter duo, which doesn't bode well for future Juddheads. Then again, we've already learned final doesn't always mean the end when it comes to the Judds, so time will tell".{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/music/article_5105938a-00b8-11e0-9eaa-0017a4a78c22.html |title=Judds deliver playful show at Family Arena |author=Johnson, Kevin C. |date=6 December 2010 |work=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z27eyWYx?url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/music/article_5105938a-00b8-11e0-9eaa-0017a4a78c22.html |archivedate=29 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} At the EnergySolutions Arena, Tom Wharton (''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]'') says that the Judds were "going out in styles". He further comments, "The pair utilized a video screen behind them for retrospective moments, showing family photos and highlights from their career, as well as two big screens on either side of the stage that allowed an appreciative crowd of about 5,000 a chance to enjoy closeup views of the performers".{{cite web|url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/home/50847253-76/wynonna-daughter-naomi-judds.html.csp |title=Last Encore by the Judds is rousing success |author=Wharton, Tom |date=9 December 2010 |work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z27pYGBb?url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/home/50847253-76/wynonna-daughter-naomi-judds.html.csp |archivedate=29 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} At the ARCO Arena, Carla Meyer (''[[The Sacramento Bee]]'') notes The Judds provided an intimate show, reminding the audience of the "good ol' days" She continues, "But the familiarity goes beyond song. Naomi, 64, and Wynonna, 46, long ago charmed and confided their ways into fans' hearts by publicly discussing their health woes, tricky family dynamics and Wynonna's weight battles and bad luck with men. Whether through their many appearances on "Oprah" or osmosis, you feel like you know them".{{cite web|url=http://www.sacbee.com/2010/12/14/3254918/much-like-old-times-for-the-judds.html |title=Much like old times for the Judds in charming show at Arco |author=Meyer, Carla |date= |work=[[The Sacramento Bee]] |accessdate=27 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z28092o6?url=http://www.sacbee.com/2010/12/14/3254918/much-like-old-times-for-the-judds.html |archivedate=29 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{The Judds}} [[Category:2010 concert tours]] [[Category:2011 concert tours]] [[Category:The Judds concert tours]] [[Category:Farewell concert tours]] [[Category:The Judds]]

==Club and provincial tournaments==
===Intercontinental=== *[[Super Rugby]] — teams from Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Argentina and Japan (known originally as Super 10 then Super 12 and later as Super 14; "Super Rugby" officially adopted from 2011). Also informally known as "Super 15". *[[Pro14]] — now Guinness Pro14, because of the league's sponsorship by [[Guinness]]: provincial/regional teams from Ireland, Italy, Scotland, South Africa and Wales. The competition began as the Celtic League, restricted to the three Celtic nations; became Pro12 when two Italian teams joined in 2010–11 and Pro14 when two South African teams joined in 2017–18.

==Sevens tournaments== {{see also|Rugby sevens}} *[[Rugby World Cup Sevens]] — Sponsored by World Rugby, and held every four years, this was the highest prize in the [[rugby sevens|Sevens]] version of the game before the introduction of sevens to the Olympics in [[Rugby sevens at the 2016 Summer Olympics|2016]]. It was initially planned for the [[2013 Rugby World Cup Sevens|2013]] edition to be the last, but it was later decided to retain the World Cup Sevens and establish a new four-year cycle starting in [[2018 Rugby World Cup Sevens|2018]]. *[[World Rugby Sevens Series]] — Annual WR-sponsored series of tournaments for men's national Sevens teams. As of the upcoming [[2017–18 World Rugby Sevens Series|2017–18 series]], the events in the series are (in order of play): **[[Dubai Sevens]] **[[South Africa Sevens]] **[[Australian Sevens]] **[[Wellington Sevens|New Zealand Sevens]] **[[USA Sevens]] **[[Canada Sevens]] **[[Hong Kong Sevens]], traditionally the biggest annual event in Sevens **[[Singapore Sevens]] **[[France Sevens]] **[[London Sevens]] *[[World Rugby Women's Sevens Series]] — Annual WR-sponsored series of tournaments for women's national Sevens teams. As of the most recent [[2016–17 World Rugby Women's Sevens Series|2016–17 series]], the events are (in order of play): **[[Dubai Women's Sevens]] **[[Australian Women's Sevens]] **[[USA Women's Sevens]] **[[Japan Women's Sevens]] **[[Canada Women's Sevens]] **[[France Women's Sevens]] *[[The National Schools Sevens]] - held at Rosslyn Park, in England, the biggest sevens competition in the world. News, photos and up to the minute results can be found on the official website [http://www.ns7.co.uk]. Results can also be seen on [http://www.schoolsrugby.co.uk/ The Schools' Rugby Website] *[[Commonwealth Games]] — Quadrennial; most recent tournament in [[Rugby sevens at the 2014 Commonwealth Games|2014]]. Men only through 2014; first women's event to be held in 2018. * Other: ** [[Amsterdam Sevens]] ** [[Bangkok Sevens]] ** [[Benidorm Sevens]] ** [[Bogota Sevens]] ** [[Caldy Sevens]] ** [[Cape Fear Sevens]] ** [[Caribbean Sevens]] ** [[Cayman Sevens]] ** [[Cwmtawe Sevens]] ** [[Heidelberg Sevens]] ** [[Henley Sevens]] ** [[Kinsale Sevens]] ** [[Kiama Sevens]] ** [[Lisbon Sevens]] ** [[Melrose Sevens]] ** [[Middlesex Sevens]] ** [[Neuchatel Sevens]] ** [[New York Sevens]] ** [[Northern Sevens]] ** [[Punta del Este Sevens]] ** [[Rome Sevens]] ** [[Safari Sevens]] ** [[Scandinavian Sevens]] ** [[Singapore Sevens]] ** [[Sofia Sevens]] ** [[Santa Teresa Sevens]] ** [[Sri Lanka Sevens]]

{{Infobox company | name = LiveSquare Entertainment | logo = LiveSquare Logo.png | type = [[Private limited company|Private]] | industry = Entertainment | founded = {{Start date and age|2007}} | founder = | defunct = | hq_location_city = [[Dhaka]] | hq_location_country = Bangladesh | area_served = [[Bangladesh]] | products = {{ublist|[[RockNation]]|The Wireless Sessions|Meets|Bangladesh Music Week|Thrillectronica|The ABC Generation}} | num_employees = [[Full-time]]: 6
[[Part-time]]: 100+ | num_employees_year = | homepage = {{url|thelivesquare.com}} }} '''LiveSquare Entertainment''' is an entertainment company originating from [[Bangladesh]], founded in 2007 by [[entrepreneur]] Nafis Ahmed.{{cite news|last1=Basher|first1=Naziba|title=Livesquare Experiences|url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/livesquare-experiences/|work=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)]]|date=19 May 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Nahian|first1=Shan|title=Exclusive enterprising entrepreneurs|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/weekend/2014/jan/04/exclusive-enterprising-entrepreneurs|work=[[Dhaka Tribune]]|date=4 January 2014}} Its services include festival management, artist management, global bookings and tour management, and production and sale of party lifestyle merchandise{{Cite web|title = When fashion meets music|url = http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/when-fashion-meets-music/|website = The Daily Star|accessdate = 2015-12-29}} and original art creations{{Cite web|title = LifeStyle|url = http://archive.thedailystar.net/lifestyle/2012/08/03/back.htm|website = archive.thedailystar.net|accessdate = 2015-12-29}} LiveSquare has organized many festivals featuring local{{Cite web|title = Rock Strata: One Last Live {{!}} Daily sun|url = http://www.daily-sun.com/home/printnews/3846|website = www.daily-sun.com|accessdate = 2015-12-29}}{{Cite web|title = RockNation III {{!}} Dhaka Tribune|url = http://www.dhakatribune.com/arts-amp-culture/2013/dec/12/rocknation-iii|website = www.dhakatribune.com|accessdate = 2015-12-29}} and international artists, and for the deployment of high-profile Bangladeshi artists such as [[Shironamhin]],{{Cite web|title = Shironamhin {{!}} Galle Music Festival|url = http://www.gallemusicfestival.org/showcase/shironamhin/|website = www.gallemusicfestival.org|access-date = 2016-01-29}} [[Chirkutt]]{{Cite web|title = Jaffna Music Festival : BANGLADESH Chirkutt Band|url = http://jmf2013.blogspot.com/2013/02/bangladesh-chirkutt-band.html|website = Jaffna Music Festival|date = 2013-02-24|access-date = 2016-01-29|first = Jaffna Music|last = Festival}} and Band Lalon{{Cite web|title = All kinds of fusion|url = http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2015/05/24/spe-fes-01.asp|website = www.sundayobserver.lk|access-date = 2016-01-29}} to international festivals in [[Sri Lanka]] and [[Norway]]. LiveSquare has worked with international cultural entities such as [[Concerts Norway|Rikskonsertene: Concerts Norway]],{{Cite web|title = Partners - Rikskonsertene|url = https://www.rikskonsertene.no/english/international/bangladesh3/samarbeidspartnere/|website = www.rikskonsertene.no|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} [[Goethe Institute Dhaka]] and EMK Center,{{Cite web|title = Get To Know LiveSquare Bangladesh|url = http://music2dealblog.com/2014/03/26/get-to-know-livesquare-bangladesh/|website = Music2Deal|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} as well as with diplomatic missions such as the [[List of diplomatic missions of Norway|Norwegian Embassy]]{{cite news|title=Press Release: Norwegian rock-band to headline Wireless Sessions|url=http://www.norway.org.bd/News_and_events/Culture/Press-Release-Norwegian-rock-band-headlines-Wireless-Sessions-/#.VqT8APl97IW|work=[[List of diplomatic missions of Norway#Asia|Norway Embassy at Bangladesh]]|date=8 November 2012}} and the [[List of diplomatic missions of Switzerland#Asia|Embassy of Switzerland in Bangladesh]]. ==History== === 2007-2010 === Initially started by Nafis Ahmed{{Cite web|title = NAFIS AHMED At the Root of Live Square|url = http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/nafis-ahmed-at-the-root-of-live-square/|website = The Daily Star|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} while he was a student in his sophomore year at [[Institute of Business Administration, University of Dhaka|IBA-DU]], LiveSquare became known with a series of lounge concerts under the banner of [[The Wireless Sessions]]{{Cite web|title = Livesquare Experiences|url = http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/livesquare-experiences/|website = The Daily Star|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} featuring bands such as [[Arbovirus (band)|Arbovirus]], [[Shunno]], [[Artcell]], [[Cryptic Fate]] and [[Nemesis (Bangladeshi band)|Nemesis]], in a time when the lounge music scene in [[Dhaka]] was in its infancy.{{cite news |title=Return of The Wireless Sessions |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/campus/2009/07/01/wireless.htm |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=2016-01-03}} LiveSquare also organized and executed several one-off concerts during this time, including a fundraising concert for the victims of the hurricane [[Cyclone Sidr]].{{Cite web|title = Amader Gaan & ADTL Unplugged Concert 08'|url = http://archive.thedailystar.net/campus/2008/01/03/feature_concert.htm|website = archive.thedailystar.net|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} LiveSquare went on a year-long hiatus in 2010 following Ahmed's graduation and subsequent employment at a reputed marketing agency. === 2011-2012 === LiveSquare organized several new events in 2011, such as the tribute concert Titans: [[Iron Maiden]]{{Cite web|title = TITANS: IRON MAIDEN A Live-Square Concert|url = http://archive.thedailystar.net/rising/2011/06/01/special.htm|website = The Daily Star|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} and The ABC Generation{{Cite web|title = THE ABC GENERATION RELOADED|url = http://archive.thedailystar.net/rising/2012/04/02/special.htm|website = The Daily Star|accessdate = 2015-12-28}}{{Cite web|title = New generation popular bands rock huge crowd : Dhaka Mirror|url = http://www.dhakamirror.com/uncategorized/new-generation-popular-bands-rock-huge-crowd/|website = www.dhakamirror.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} series. LiveSquare worked with international entities to bring in international artists to Bangladesh, such as Norwegian-Bangladeshi musician Kohinoor Nordberg, Swiss funk rock band Starch,{{Cite web|title = Music to intertwine lifestyle|url = http://archive.thedailystar.net/lifestyle/2012/08/03/back.htm|website = The Daily Star|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} American guitarist [[Ken Stringfellow]],{{Cite web|title = Ken Stringfellow's Bangladesh tour|url = http://news.priyo.com/node/45433|website = Priyo News|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} Norwegian pop rock outfit Casa Murilo,{{Cite web|title = ForethoughtPR : News & Events|url = http://www.forethoughtpr.com/Content.php?pageType=NewsEvents&Type=10&id=241&category=Resource%2520id%2520#12&Page=News_Events|website = www.forethoughtpr.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} multinational world music ensemble OK World{{Cite web|title = ForethoughtPR : News & Events|url = http://www.forethoughtpr.com/Content.php?pageType=NewsEvents&Type=10&id=186&category=Resource%2520id%2520#12&Page=News_Events|website = www.forethoughtpr.com|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} and various others, performing alongside Bangladeshi artists. The Wireless Sessions were also brought back during this time.{{cite news |title = The Wireless Sessions, Season 7 |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/lifestyle/2012/11/02/page01.htm |newspaper=The Daily Star |date=13 November 2012 |accessdate = }} === 2013-2016 === [[File:RockNation VI- Resurrection.jpg|thumb|562x562px|RockNation VI: Resurrection]] LiveSquare sent Bangladeshi artists such as Chirkutt,{{Cite web|url = http://www.norway.org.bd/Documents/PR_Nritya%20Nandan.docx|title = PR: Nritya Nandan|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} [[Shironamhin]]{{Cite web|title = Shironamhin to perform in Colombo and Gall|url = http://news.priyo.com/node/102304|website = Priyo News|accessdate = 2015-12-29}}{{Cite web|title = Galle Concert {{!}} Groups {{!}} Galle Music Festival|url = http://www.gallemusicfestival.org/group/galle-concert/|website = www.gallemusicfestival.org|accessdate = 2015-12-29}} and Band Lalon{{Cite web|title = Jaffna Music Festival|url = http://www.norway.org.bd/News_and_events/Culture/Jaffna-Music-Festival/|website = www.norway.org.bd|accessdate = 2015-12-28}} to perform at international festivals in Sri Lanka and Norway. In 2013, LiveSquare started the [[RockNation]]{{Cite web|title = ROCKNATION|url = http://archive.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/rocknation/|website = The Daily Star|accessdate = 2015-12-28}}{{Cite
