{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Lohri |observedby = Sikhs, Hindus |type = seasonal |longtype = Religious, cultural |image = Happy Lohri.jpg |caption = Lohri Bonfire |nickname = [[Lal Loi]] |celebrations = Bonfire, song and dance (Bhangra and Gidda ) |significance = Midwinter festival, celebration of Winter Solstice |relatedto = [[Maghi]] - [[Makar Sankranti]] celebrated next day}} '''Lohri''' is a popular winter time Punjabi folk festival, celebrated primarily by Sikhs and Hindus from the [[Punjab region]] of [[Indian subcontinent]].{{cite book|author1=S. Warrier|author2=John G. Walshe|title=Dates and Meanings of Religious and Other Multi-Ethnic Festivals, 2002-2005|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R6VQ_YRIPl0C|year=2001|publisher=Foulsham |isbn=978-0-572-02659-2|page=112}}, Quote: "Lohri is the winter festival of Punjab and is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs."{{cite book|author=Colleen Taylor Sen|title=Food Culture in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YIyV_5wrplMC&pg=PA142|year=2004|publisher=Greenwood Publishing |isbn=978-0-313-32487-1|page=142}}, Quote: "In the Punjab, this festival is called Lohri and is celebrated by Sikhs and Hindus with bonfires" The significance and legends about the Lohri festival are many and these link the festival to the [[Punjab region]].[http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/what-is-lohri-why-is-lohri-celebrated-sunder-mundriye-dulla-bhatti-punjabi-folklore-rabi-crop/1/569416.html What is Lohri? Why is it celebrated?], Somya Abrol, India Today, (January 13, 2017){{cite web|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1040124/asp/opinion/story_2816036.asp |title= The Telegraph - Calcutta : Opinion|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}} Many people believe the festival commemorates the passing of the [[winter solstice]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/1998/98jul19/science.htm|title=The Tribune...Science Tribune|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}}[http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/gyan-zone/festival-binge/28107.html The Tribune Festival binge: Amarjot Kaur 10 January 2015]Celebrating with the Robin Hood of the Punjab and all his friends! Nottingham Post 13 01 2014 [http://www.nottinghampost.com/Celebrating-Robin-Hood-Punjab-friends/story-20434739-detail/story.html] Lohri marks the end of winter season, and is a traditional welcome of longer days and sun's journey to the northern hemisphere by Sikhs and Hindus in the Punjab region of the Indian subcontinent. It is observed the night before [[Makar Sankranti]], also known as [[Maghi]], and according to the solar part of the lunisolar [[Bikrami calendar]] and typically falls about the same date every year (January 13).{{cite book|author=Dr. H.S. Singha|title=Sikh Studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nRodBu9seiIC&pg=PA101|year=2005|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=978-81-7010-245-8|pages=101–102}} Lohri is an official gazetted holiday in the state of Punjab (India),[http://www.hindustantimes.com/punjab/punjab-notifies-gazetted-restricted-holidays-for-2016/story-IdSI5D43hsqiu8i98G1YWJ.html Punjab notifies gazetted, restricted holidays for 2016], The Hindustan Times (2016) where the festival is celebrated by Sikhs, Hindus, Muslims and Christians,Chauhan, Ramesh K. (1995) Punjab and the nationality question in India. Deep and Deep Publications [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=X2RuAAAAMAAJ&dq=hindu+muslim+sikh+christian+lohri&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=lohri] but it is not a holiday in Punjab (Pakistan).[https://schools.punjab.gov.pk/system/files/PublicHolidays2017.pdf#overlay-context=holidays Public and Optional Holidays], Government of Punjab, Lahore, Pakistan (2017) It is, however, observed by Sikhs and some Punjabi Muslims and Christians in [[Pakistan]] as well.[http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Punjab-celebrates-the-Lohri:-From-culture,-an-invitation-to-a-springtime-of-peace-and-unity-26972.html] Asian News Jan 2013: Lohri celebrated in Faislabad, Punjab, Pakistan ==Date== Lohri is linked to the [[Bikrami]] calendar, and is celebrated the day before the festival of [[Maghi]] celebrated in [[India]] as [[Makar Sankranti]]. Lohri falls in the month of [[Paush]] and is set by the solar part of the lunisolar [[Punjabi calendar]] and in most years it falls on 13 January of the [[Gregorian calendar]]. ==Origins== [[File:Lohri.jpg|thumb|left|Lohri]] There are many folklores about Lohri. Lohri is the celebration of the arrival of longer days after the [[winter solstice]]. According to folklore, in ancient times Lohri was celebrated at the end of the traditional month when [[winter solstice]] occurs.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/kids/what-a-wonderful-world/article4282523.ece|title=What a wonderful world|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}}[http://www.hindustantimes.com/punjab/chandigarh/bless-the-girl/article1-988618.aspx Hindustan Times 12 01 2013] It celebrates the days getting longer as the sun proceeds on its northward journey. The day after Lohri is celebrated as [[Maghi]] [[Sankranti|Sangrand]].{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/Punjabi-pockets-warm-up-for-Lohri-bonfires/articleshow/45839012.cms|title=Punjabi pockets warm up for Lohri bonfires - Times of India|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}} In its origins, Lohri is an ancient mid winter Hindu festival, in regions near the Himalayan mountains where winter is colder than the rest of the subcontinent. Hindus traditionally lit bonfires in their yards after the weeks of the ''rabi'' season cropping work, socialized around the fire, sang and danced together as they marked the end of winter and the onset of longer days. After the night of bonfire celebrations, the Hindu would mark Makar Sankranti and go to a sacred water body such as a river or lake to bathe.{{cite book|author1=J. Gordon Melton|author2=Martin Baumann|title=Religions of the World: A Comprehensive Encyclopedia of Beliefs and Practices, 2nd Edition |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v2yiyLLOj88C&pg=PA1769 |year=2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-204-3|page=1769}} [[File:Punjabi woman smile.jpg|thumb|right|Punjabi woman waiting to participate in Gidda]] However, instead of celebrating Lohri on the eve of when [[winter solstice]] actually occurs, Punjabis celebrate it on the last day of the month during which [[winter solstice]] takes place. Lohri commemorates the passing of the [[winter solstice]].[http://www.hindustantimes.com/lifestyle/fashion/brighten-your-lohri-with-a-touch-of-tradition/article1-1305929.aspx Hindustan Times 12 January 2015 Snigdha Ahuja] ===Significance=== The ancient significance of the festival is both as a winter crop season celebration[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=HO4n549SLIgC&dq=lohri+winter+crop+celebration&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=lohri+ Harvest Celebrations, Volume 4, (2002) World Book] and a remembrance of the Sun deity (''[[Surya]]''). Lohri songs mention the Indian Sun god asking for heat and thanking him for his return. Other legends explain the celebration as a folk reverence for fire (''[[Agni]]''){{cite web | url = http://www.lohrifestival.org| title = THE LEGENDS OF LOHRI |publisher= Society for the Confluence of Festivals in India }} or the goddess of Lohri.Roy, AnjaliGera (2017) Bhangra Moves: From Ludhiana to London and Beyond. Routledge [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tCgxDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT177&dq=lohri+goddess&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjvq7mk2tnYAhWmOsAKHRPmDZkQ6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=lohri%20goddess&f=false] Yet another folklore links Lohri to the tale of [[Dulla Bhatti]]. The central theme of many Lohri songs is the legend of Dulla Bhatti, whose real name was Abdullah Bhatti and lived in Punjab during the reign of [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] Emperor [[Akbar]]. He was regarded as a hero in Punjab, for rescuing Hindu girls from being forcibly taken to be sold in slave market of the Middle East.{{cite web | url = http://www.lohrifestival.org| title = THE ORIGINS OF LOHRI |publisher= Society for the Confluence of Festivals in India }} Amongst those he saved were two girls Sundri & Mundri, who gradually became a theme of Punjab' folklore. As a part of Lohri celebrations, children go around homes singing the traditional folk songs of Lohri with "Dulla Bhatti" name included. One person sings, while others end each line with a loud "Ho!" sung in unison. After the song ends, the adult of the home is expected to give snacks and money to the singing troupe of youngsters.{{cite book|author1=Kailash Puri|author2=Eleanor Nesbitt|title=Pool of Life: The Autobiography of a Punjabi Agony Aunt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L_NWAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA34|year=2013|publisher=Sussex Academic Press|isbn=978-1-78284-067-1|pages=34–35}} ==Celebrations: Bonfire and festive foods== Lohri is celebrated with a bonfire. The lighting of bonfire during this winter festival is an ancient tradition.Page 17: From Kartik month the Sun is moving away from the earth. Ancient people lit the bonfire to reignite the return of longer days. This is a very ancient tradition. Sundar mundarye ho by Assa Singh Ghuman Waris Shah Foundation ISBN B1-7856-043-7[http://cooks.ndtv.com/article/show/lohri-special-why-food-is-fed-to-the-fire-470357 NDTV 06 12 14]{{cite web|url=http://cooks.ndtv.com/article/show/an-indian-thanksgiving-316129|title=An Indian Thanks Giving - NDTV Food|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}} [[File:(2) Raw sugar jaggery gud Punjab India.jpg|thumb|right|''Gurh'', solidifiedand unrefined sugarcane juice is a traditional festive sweet.]] In Punjab, the harvest festival Lohri is marked by eating sheaves of roasted corn from the new harvest.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=zG1H75z0EYYC&pg=RA2-PA99&dq=lohri+harvest&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi07rSX68zTAhVGBMAKHci3BfwQ6AEITTAI#v=onepage&q=lohri%20harvest&f=false Albala, Ken (2011) Food Cultures of the World Encyclopedia. ABC-CLIO] The January sugarcane harvest is celebrated in the Lohri festival.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9vMj4E6OKtQC&q=sugarcane+lohri+harvest&dq=sugarcane+lohri+harvest&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi_8Z6M7czTAhWqB8AKHU49B0AQ6AEISzAI Sinclair, Toby (1994) India.Odyssey] Sugarcane products such as gurh and gachak are central to Lohri celebrations, as are nuts which are harvested in January. The other important food item of Lohri is radish which can be harvested between October and January. Mustard greens are cultivated mainly in the winter months because the crop is suitable to the agro-climatic conditions.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cxhNAAAAYAAJ&dq=sag+lohri&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+lohri Indian Food Packer, Volume 49 (1995)] Accordingly, mustard greens are also a winter produce. It is traditional to eat [[Gajak]], [[Sarson da saag]] with [[Makki di roti]], [[radish]], ground nuts and [[jaggery]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/1999/99jan13/head6.htm#3| title=Lohri page|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}} It is also traditional to eat "til rice" which is made by mixing [[jaggery]], sesame seeds and rice.Sundar Mundarye ho by Assa Singh Bhuman Waris Shah Foundation {{ISBN|81-7856-043-7}} In some places, this dish is called 'Tricholi.' ===Collecting Lohri items and trick or treating=== In various places of the [[Punjab, India|Punjab]], about 10 to 15 days before Lohri, groups of young and teenage boys and girls go around the neighbourhood collecting logs for the Lohri bonfire. In some places, they also collect items such as grains and jaggery which are sold and the sale proceeds are divided amongst the group.Sundar mundarye ho by Assa Singh Ghuman Waris Shah Foundation ISBN B1-7856-043-7 A popular activity engaged in by boys is to select a group member to smear his face with ash and tie a rope around his waist! The idea is for the selected person to act as a deterrent for people who refrain from giving Lohri items. The boys will sing Lohri songs asking for Lohri items. If not enough is given, the householder will be given an ultimatum to either give more or the rope will be loosened. If not enough is given, then the boy who has his face smeared will try to enter the house and smash clay pots or the clay stove! ==Practices== During the day, children go from door to door singing folk songs. These children are given sweets and savories, and occasionally, money. Turning them back empty-handed is regarded inauspicious. Where families are welcoming newly-weds and new borns,{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/indore/Lohri-brightened-by-festive-spirit/articleshow/45878319.cms|title=Lohri brightened by festive spirit - Times of India|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}} the requests for treats increases. The collections gathered by the children are known as ''Lohri'' and consist of til, gachchak, crystal sugar, gur (jaggery), moongphali (peanuts) and phuliya or popcorn. Lohri is then distributed at night during the festival. Till, peanuts, popcorn and other food items are also thrown into the fire. For some, throwing food into the fire represents the burning of the old year and start the next year on [[Makar Sankranti]] The bonfire ceremony differs depending on the location in Punjab. In some parts, a small image of the folk Lohri goddess is made with gobar (cattle dung) decorating it, kindling a fire beneath it and chanting its praises. The folk Lohri goddess is believed to be an ancient aspect of the celebration, and is part of a long tradition of [[Winter solstice]] celebrations manifesting as a god or goddess.{{cite web|url=http://paganwiccan.about.com/od/yulethelongestnight/a/Winter_Sol_Gods.htm|title=Who Are the Deities of the Winter Solstice?|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}} In other parts, the Lohri fire consists of cow dung and wood with no reference to the Lohri goddess. The bonfire is lit at sunset in the main village square. People toss sesame seeds, gur, sugar-candy and ''rewaries'' on the bonfire, sit around it, sing and dance till the fire dies out. Some people perform a prayer and go around the fire. This is to show respect to the natural element of fire,[http://www.deccanherald.com/content/47133/bringing-home-sun-god.html] FirozBakht Ahmed Deccan Herald 18/01/2010 a tradition common in [[winter solstice]] celebrations. It is traditional to offer guests til, gachchak, gur, moongphali (peanuts) and phuliya or popcorn. Milk and water is also poured around the bonfire by [[Hindus]] to thank the Sun God and seeking his continued protection. Among some sections of the [[Sindhis|Sindhi]] community, the festival is traditionally celebrated as [[Lal Loi]]. On the day of Lal Loee children bring wood sticks from their grand parents and aunties and light a fire burning the sticks in the night with people enjoying, dancing and playing around the fire. The festival is gaining popularity amongst other Sindhis where Lohri is not a traditional festival.[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ludhiana/Lohri-gaiety-warms-all/articleshow/11468901.cms? Nidhin Singhi "Lohri gaiety warms all"Times of India 13 01 2012] ==Lohri and the financial year== Historically, during the 19th century, revenue for winter crops was collected either on Lohri or [[Maghi]].[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=PSpuAAAAMAAJ&dq=punjabi+collect+rent+on+lohri&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=lohri Proceedings - Punjab History Conference (2000)] ==Where celebrated== [[File:Bhangra - Global Institutes.JPG|thumb|Bhangra]] [[File:Ready to perform punjabi cultural dance" Gidha" 2013-10-26 18-05.jpg|thumb|Ready to perform Punjabi cultural dance" Gidha"]] [[File:2 dhols.jpg|thumb|2 dhols]] Lohri is celebrated to denote the last of the coldest days of winter. Apart from Punjab, Lohri is also celebrated in Delhi. Haryana and Himachal Pradesh. Lohri has been celebrated in Jammu since Mughal times.Jyoteeshwar Pathik, Diwan Chand Sharma (1980) Cultural Heritage of the Dogras. Page 106 "The festival of Lohri is said to be celebrated from Mughal time when a witch had created tyranny and horror on the Jammu Punjab border..." Light & Life Publishers [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=mZc9AAAAMAAJ&q=jammu+witch+punjab+jammu+border&dq=jammu+witch+punjab+jammu+border&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi5h8CSs9bRAhXDvBoKHYNBBoEQ6AEIGjAA] The festival is observed as [[Lal Loi]] in the [[Indian Sindhis|Sindhi]] community.{{cite web|url=http://www.theindianpanorama.news/potpourri/spirituality/lohri-the-bonfire-festival-3.html|title=LOHRI: THE BONFIRE FESTIVAL - The Indian Panorama|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyexcelsior.com/lohri-aaye-rey/|title=Lohri Aaye Rey|date=13 January 2016|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.scoopnews.in/det.aspx?q=53555|title=Dr Jitendra organises joint celebration of 'Lohri', 'Bihu' festivals - Scoop News Jammu Kashmir|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://scroll.in/article/801803/lohri-legends-the-tale-of-abdullah-khan-dullah-bhatti-the-punjabi-who-led-a-revolt-against-akbar|title=Lohri legends: the tale of Abdullah Khan 'Dullah' Bhatti, the Punjabi who led a revolt against Akbar|first=Shoaib|last=Daniyal|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}} ==Celebrations== In houses that have recently had a marriage or childbirth, Lohri celebrations will reach a higher pitch of excitement. Punjabis usually have private Lohri celebrations, in their houses. Lohri rituals are performed, with the accompaniment of special Lohri songs. Singing and dancing form an intrinsic part of the celebrations. People wear their brightest clothes and come to dance the [[Bhangra (dance)|bhangra]] and [[gidda]] to the beat of the [[dhol]]. Punjabi songs are sung, and everybody rejoices. Sarson da saag and makki di roti is usually served as the main course at a Lohri dinner. Lohri is a great occasion that holds great importance for farmers. However, people residing in urban areas also celebrate Lohri, as this festival provides the opportunity to interact with family and friends. ==Lohri songs== There are many Lohri songs. For example, the following song which has words to express gratitude to Dulla Bhatti (the 'ho's are in chorus):{{cite news | url = http://www.lohrifestival.org/lohri-boys-songs.html | title = Dhulla Bhatti Song}}

==Other legends of the origin of Lohri festival== Some people believe that Lohri has derived its name from Loi, the wife of Saint Kabir. There is a legend amongst some people that Lohri comes from the word 'loh', which means the light and the warmness of fire. Lohri is also called lohi in rural Punjab. According to another legend Holika and Lohri were sisters. While the former perished in the Holi fire, the latter survived with Prahlad. Eating of til (sesame seeds) and rorhi is considered to be essential on Lohri day. Perhaps the words til and rorhi merged to become tilorhi, which eventually got shortened to Lohri. ==Other parts of India== Lohri coincides with the festivals of [[Pongal]], [[Bhogali Bihu]] and [[Bhogi]]. The day preceding Pongal in Tamil Nadu and Makara Sankranti in Andhra Pradesh is called [[Bhogi]](భోగి) this is when people discard old and derelict things and concentrate on new things causing change or transformation. At dawn people light a bonfire with logs of wood, other solid-fuels and wooden furniture at home that are no longer useful. The disposal of derelict things is where all old habits, vices, attachment to relations and material things are sacrificed in the sacrificial fire of the knowledge of Rudra, known as the "Rudra Gita Gyana Yagya". It represents realization, transformation and purification of the soul by imbibing and inculcating divine virtues. ==Similar festivals in other countries== [[Winter solstice]] festivals have been incorporated into other festivals which are celebrated in various regions around the world. The festival of [[Yule]] is observed during [[Christmas]] celebrations whereby a log is burnt to commemorate the [[winter solstice]]. The festival of [[Hogmanay]] is celebrated on new year’s day. The fire festival of Stonehaven in [[Scotland]] is the direct descendant of lighting winter solstice bonfires.{{cite web|url=http://www.historic-uk.com/HistoryUK/HistoryofScotland/The-History-of-Hogmanay/|title=The History of Hogmanay|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}} Another event is observed every 11 January when the flaming Clavie (a barrel full of staves) is carried round in Burghead and is wedged on the Doorie Hill. When it is burnt out, people take the smouldering embers to bring good luck for the coming year.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=UViEbWQOSd0C&pg=PA71&lpg=PA71&dq=Clavie+at+Burghead+winter+solstice&source=bl&ots=kgSsriEtSD&sig=yNrnt2YaiRzVGxxWyjOvhWu-DyU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5Ou4VKqaDIzV7Qbwq4DYBw&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=Clavie%20at%20Burghead%20winter%20solstice&f=false] the Magic Arts in Celtic Britain Lewis Spence ==See also== * [[Makar Sankranti]] * [[Pongal]] * [[Bhogali Bihu]] * [[Sankranti]] * [[Winter Solstice]] * [[Maghi]] * [[Hogmanay]] ==References== {{Reflist|25em}} ==External links== {{Punjab, India}} {{HinduFestivals}} {{Winter solstice}} {{Punjabi fairs and festivals}} {{Punjabi festivals}} [[Category:Punjabi festivals]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian January observances]] [[Category:Hindu festivals]] [[Category:Religious festivals in India]] [[Category:Festivals in Punjab, Pakistan]] [[Category:Punjab]] [[Category:Harvest festivals in India]] [[Category:Winter festivals]] [[Category:Islamic festivals in India]] [[Category:Sikh festivals]]

{{Other people}} {{Infobox person | name = Mary Rogers | image = | birth_name = Mary Cecilia Rogers | caption = Marianne Aminoff (1940s) | birth_date = 1820 | birth_place = [[Lyme, Connecticut]], USA | death_date = July 28, 1841 (age 21–22) | death_place = [[Hoboken, New Jersey]], USA | mother = Phoebe Rogers | nationality = [[Americans|American]] }} '''Mary Cecilia Rogers''' (born c. 1820 – found dead July 28, 1841) was an American [[murder]] victim whose story became a national sensation.
Rogers was a noted beauty who worked in a New York [[tobacco]] store, which attracted the custom of many distinguished men, clearly on her account. When her body was found in the Hudson River, she was assumed to have been the victim of [[gang]] violence. However, one witness swore that she was dumped after a failed abortion attempt, while her boyfriend's suicide-note suggested possible involvement on his part. Rogers' death remains unexplained. She inspired [[Edgar Allan Poe]]'s pioneering [[detective fiction|detective story]] "[[The Mystery of Marie Rogêt]]".
==Early life== Mary Rogers was probably born in 1820 in [[Lyme, Connecticut]], though her birth records have not survived.<ref name=Stashower>{{cite book |title=The Beautiful Cigar Girl |last=Stashower |first=Daniel |publisher=PenguinBooks |location=New York |year=2006 |pages=20–23 |isbn=0-525-94981-X}}</ref> She was a beautiful young woman who grew up as the only child of her widowed mother. At the age of twenty, Mary lived in the [[boarding house]] that was run by her mother, although it was her amazing beauty that made her the talk of the neighborhood.<ref name=Romeo>{{cite book |title=The Beautiful Cigar Girl |last=vitelli |first=Romeo |location=Toronto |year=2011 |url=http://drvitelli.typepad.com/providentia/2011/05/the-mary-rogers-case.html |isbn=0-525-94981-X}}</ref> Her father died in a steamboat explosion when she was 17 years old and she took a job as a [[clerk]] in a tobacco shop owned by John Anderson in [[New York City]].<ref name=Sova>{{cite book |title=Edgar Allan Poe: A to Z |last=Sova |first=Dawn B. |publisher=Checkmark Books |location=New York |edition=Paperback |year=2001 |pages=212–213 |isbn=0-8160-4161-X}}</ref> Anderson paid her a generous wage in part because her physical attractiveness brought in many customers. One customer wrote that he spent an entire afternoon at the store only to exchange "teasing glances" with her. Another admirer published a poem in the ''[[New York Herald]]'' referring to her [[heaven]]-like smile and her star-like eyes.<ref name=Stashower/> Some of her customers included notable literary figures [[James Fenimore Cooper]], [[Washington Irving]], and [[Fitz-Greene Halleck]].<ref>{{cite book|last=McNamara |first=Joseph |title=The Justice Story: True Tales of Murder, Mystery, Mayhem |publisher=Sports Publishing LLC |year=2000 |page=99 |isbn=1-58261-285-4}}</ref>
==First disappearance== On October 5, 1838, the [[newspaper]] New York ''[[The Sun (New York)|Sun]]'' reported that "Miss Mary Cecilia Rogers" had disappeared from her home.<ref name=Sova/> Her mother, Phoebe, said she found a [[suicide]] note which the local [[coroner]] analyzed and said revealed a "fixed and unalterable determination to destroy herself".<ref name=Stashower/> The next day, however, the ''Times and Commercial Intelligence'' reported that the disappearance was a [[hoax]] and that Rogers only went to visit a friend in [[Brooklyn]].<ref name=Sova/> The ''Sun'' had previously published a story known as the [[Great Moon Hoax]] in 1835, causing controversy.<ref>{{cite book |last=Willis |first=Jim |title=100 Media Moments that Changed America |year=2010 |publisher=Greenwood Press |location=Santa Barbara, Calif. |isbn=978-0-313-35517-2 |page=19}}</ref> Some suggested this return was actually the hoax, evidenced by Rogers's failure to return to work immediately. When she finally resumed working at the tobacco shop, one newspaper suggested the whole event was a publicity stunt managed by Anderson.<ref name=Stashower/>
==Murder== On July 25, 1841, Rogers told her [[Engagement|fiancé]], Daniel Payne, that she would be visiting her aunt and other family members.<ref name=Sova/> Three days later, on July 28, the police found her [[Cadaver|corpse]] floating in the [[Hudson River]] in [[Hoboken, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The Poe Log: A Documentary Life of Edgar Allan Poe 1809–1849 |last1=Thomas |first1=Dwight |last2=Jackson |first2=David K. |publisher=G. K. Hall & Co |location=New York |year=1987 |pages=336–337 |isbn=0-7838-1401-1}}</ref> Referred to as the "Beautiful Cigar Girl", the mystery of her death was sensationalized by newspapers and received national attention. The details of the case suggested she was murdered, or dumped by abortionist [[Madame Restell]] after a failed procedure.<ref>{{cite book|last=Collins |first=Paul |title=The Murder of the Century |publisher=Random House |year=2011 |isbn=978-0-307-59220-0 |page=128}}</ref> Months later, the inquest still ongoing, her grief-stricken fiancé Daniel Payne committed suicide by overdosing on [[laudanum]] during a bout of heavy drinking. A remorseful note was found among the papers on his person where he died near [[Sybil's Cave]] on October 7, 1841, reading: "To the World – here I am on the very spot. May [[God]] forgive me for my misspent life." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/classics/mary_rogers/5.html|title=The Murder Mystery of Mary Rogers|author=Douglass MacGowan|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080730060532/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/classics/mary_rogers/5.html|archivedate=July 30, 2008|website=www.trutv.com}}</ref>
The story, much publicized by the press, also emphasized the ineptitude and corruption of the city's watchmen system of law enforcement.<ref>{{cite book |title=NYPD: A City and Its Police |last1=Lardner |first1=James |last2=Reppetto |first2=Thomas |publisher=Owl Books |year=2000 |isbn=0-8050-6737-X |pages=18–21}}</ref> At the time, New York City's population of 320,000 was served by an archaic force, consisting of one night watch, one hundred city marshals, thirty-one constables, and fifty-one police officers.<ref name="lankevich-p84">{{cite book |title=American Metropolis: A History of New York City |author=Lankevich, George L. |publisher=NYU Press |year=1998 |isbn=0-8147-5186-5 |pages=84–85}}</ref>
The popular theory was that Rogers was a victim of [[gang]] violence.<ref name=Silverman205>{{cite book |title=Edgar A. Poe: Mournful and Never-Ending Remembrance |last=Silverman |first=Kenneth |authorlink=Kenneth Silverman |publisher=Harper Perennial |location=New York |edition=Paperback |year=1991 |page=205 |isbn=0-06-092331-8}}</ref> In November 1842, Frederica Loss came forward and swore that Rogers' death was the result of a failed [[abortion]] attempt. Police refused to believe her story and the case remained unsolved.<ref name=Sova/> Interest in the story waned nine weeks later when the press began publicizing a different, unrelated murder case,<ref>{{cite book |last=Nelson |first=Randy F. |title=The Almanac of American Letters |location=Los Altos, California |publisher=William Kaufmann, Inc. |year=1981 |page=183 |isbn=0-86576-008-X}}</ref> that of [[John C. Colt]]'s murder of Samuel Adams.<ref name=walsh>{{cite book|title=Poe the Detective: the Curious Circumstances Behind The Mystery of Marie Roget |last=Walsh |first=John |page=2 |year=1968 |publisher= Rutgers University Press |quote="The Oblong Box" (not a story of crime as Poe told it) is based in part on the murder of the printer, Samuel Adams by John C. Colt, which succeeded the death of Mary Rogers as the leading sensational topic for the American press.}}</ref>
==In fiction== [[File:Mystery of Marie Roget.jpg|thumb|right|1853 illustration for "[[The Mystery of Marie Rogêt]]", a story inspired by the death of Mary Rogers]] Rogers' story was fictionalized most notably by [[Edgar Allan Poe]] as "[[The Mystery of Marie Rogêt]]" (1842). The action of the story was relocated to [[Paris]] and the victim's body found in the River [[Seine]].<ref name=Silverman205/> Poe presented the story as a sequel to "[[The Murders in the Rue Morgue]]" (1841), commonly considered the first modern [[detective fiction|detective story]], and included its main character, [[C. Auguste Dupin]]. As Poe wrote in a letter: "under the pretense of showing how Dupin... unravelled the mystery of Marie's assassination, I, in fact, enter into a very rigorous analysis of the real tragedy in New York."<ref>{{cite book |title=The Cryptographic Imagination: Secret Writing from Edgar Poe to the Internet |last=Rosenheim |first=Shawn James |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press |location=Baltimore |year=1997 |pages=68–69 |isbn=978-0-8018-5332-6}}</ref> In the story, Dupin suggests several possible solutions but never actually names the murderer.<ref>{{cite book |title=Edgar Allan Poe: His Life and Legacy |last=Meyers |first=Jeffrey |publisher=Cooper Square Press |location=New York |edition=Paperback |year=1992 |page=135 |isbn=0-8154-1038-7}}</ref>

{{POV|date=October 2013}} The '''Michaud Affair''' (in French '''''l'Affaire Michaud''''') was a [[political]] controversy in [[Quebec]] that began in 2000. It revolved around the comments of [[Parti Québécois]] supporter [[Yves Michaud]], those of the [[Jewish Quebecer|Quebec Jewish community]] (through the [[B'nai B'rith]] organization) and the subsequent [[censure]] motion from the [[National Assembly of Quebec]] members of parliament.
==The Affair==
===CKAC Interview=== What has been called the "Michaud Affair" started on December 5, 2000, in an interview on the [[Montreal]] radio station [[CKAC]]. Talk show host [[Paul Arcand]] asked: "Don't you feel that there is a lack of interest of a good part of the population on the question of sovereignty and the national question, people who have had enough, for whom it is all over, (who say) let's move on to something else?".
To which Yves Michaud replied: "Well, I will tell you an anecdote. I was... I went to get my hair cut about a month ago. There was a [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] [[Senate of Canada|senator]] who I will not name who doesn't speak [French]... even though he represents a French-speaking riding and who asked me: 'Are you still a separatist, Yves?' I said 'Yes, yes I am separatist just as you are Jewish. It took 2000 years for your people to have its homeland in Israel.' I said: 'Me, whether it takes 10, 50, or 100 more years it can wait.' So he told me: 'It's not the same.'"
"It's never the same for them. So I said: it is not the same? The [[Armenian Genocide|Armenians]] did not suffer, the Palestinians did not suffer, the [[Rwandan Genocide|Rwandans]] did not suffer. It's always (just) you. You are the only people who suffered in the history of humanity."
"After that, I was fed up. And here we are, I am completely indignant... that some suggested to rename the [[Montreal Metro|metro]] station [named after] [[Lionel Groulx]], who was the spiritual father of two generations of Quebecers and is almost a Quebec idol. It's the [[B'nai B'rith]] that did that, which was the extremist phalange... There has been world Zionism... "{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}}
The Senator mentioned was [[Leo Kolber]], Michaud later revealed.<ref>http://faculty.marianopolis.edu/c.belanger/quebechistory/docs/michaud/20.htm</ref>
===Estates-General=== On December 12, 2000, the director of B'nai B'rith's Quebec chapter, [[Robert Libman]], sent a memo to then Premier [[Lucien Bouchard]] requesting that he stop Michaud from being the PQ's candidate in the Mercier riding.<ref>http://faculty.marianopolis.edu/c.belanger/quebechistory/docs/michaud/20.htm</ref> <ref>http://faculty.marianopolis.edu/c.belanger/quebechistory/docs/michaud/30.htm</ref>
On December 13, 2000, Michaud presented a memorandum to Quebec's "[[Estates-General on the situation of the French language]]". He abandoned some parts of his text to say this, in front of members of the [[B'nai B'rith]] who were waiting their turn to speak:{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}}
"[[Lionel Groulx|Groulx]] invited us 'to have, like the Jews, their rough will to survive, their invincible spirit of solidarity, their imperishable moral armor'. And the historian was giving the example of the Jewish people as a model to be followed so that Quebecers affirm their own national identity and fully assume the heritage of their history. Groulx, who is one of the intellectual guides of two generations of Quebecers and one whose name some wanted to see removed from the [[Lionel-Groulx (Montreal Metro)|Lionel-Groulx station]] a few years ago, to probably replace it by the "[[Mordecai Richler]]" station, the [[René Lévesque Boulevard]] by, no doubt, "[[Ariel Sharon]]" boulevard, the [[Jacques-Cartier Place]] by the "[[Howard Galganov|Galganov]]" place, and so on. It is a little satirical, it is a little bit jokingly that I say that, but I think that some others are exaggerating and going a little too far. Immigrants, we want some. Yes, as much as possible and pushing up to the limit of our capacities to welcome them. Immigrants who will not only have rights but also responsibilities with regard to one of the most generous societies in the world which welcomes them with open arms and wallets, immigrants with responsibilities, that is, understanding and speaking our language, open to our culture, our way of working, of doing things, of interpreting the world in the French language and accompanying us on the road which leads us to the control of all the tools for our development (...) There is an ethnic vote against the sovereignty of the people of Quebec. If we do not integrate our immigrants, well then, we will enter on the slope of the Louisianization, and folklorization of our society."{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}}
===Condemnation by the National Assembly===
On December 13, 2000, the leader of the opposition [[Quebec Liberal Party|Liberal Party]], [[Jean Charest]], presented to the [[National Assembly of Quebec]] a motion condemning references to "an ethnic vote against the sovereignty of the people of Quebec" and speaking of B'nai Brith as "an extremist group against quebecers and against sovereignty",<ref>http://faculty.marianopolis.edu/c.belanger/quebechistory/docs/michaud/08.htm</ref> as expressed by Yves Michaud at the Estates-General.
The Premier at the time, Lucien Bouchard, affirmed that he had been aware of similar remarks made by Michaud three (sic) days earlier and that he had asked Michaud to tone down his remarks in the Estates-General. Since Michaud did not do so and even added fuel to the fire, Bouchard therefore condemned the remarks in the name of his party and the government. The motion was adopted unanimously by the National Assembly.
==Interpretation== {{Original research|section|date=October 2013}} The Michaud Affair re-awakened the bitter, very emotional and controversial divisions within the Parti Québécois between proponents of "soft nationalists" (aka "nationalistes modérés") versus "hard liners" (aka "purs et durs"). <ref>http://faculty.marianopolis.edu/c.belanger/quebechistory/docs/michaud/13.htm</ref> <ref>http://faculty.marianopolis.edu/c.belanger/quebechistory/docs/michaud/14.htm</ref> <ref>http://faculty.marianopolis.edu/c.belanger/quebechistory/docs/michaud/15.htm</ref>
This Affair must be interpreted in the context of long-standing historical tensions between some more radical factions within the Quebec nationalist movement and the English-speaking and Jewish communities of Quebec ("Anglophones"). Consequently, whereas most members of the Anglophone community and the general media consider Michaud's allegations to lean towards antisemitism,{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} to Michaud supporters within the PQ and the sovereigntist movement generally the Michaud Affair is the result of censorship and defamation against the "ethnic Quebecer" minority and its "rightful quest for political independence and autonomy".{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Thus, this question is an emotional one for both the PQ's ethnic-nationalist fanatics and the Anglophone zealots.
==Aftermath== On December 19, 2000, former Quebec Premier [[Jacques Parizeau]] and many others signed an open letter condemning the hasty resolution and supporting Michaud's. The letter was published in several newspapers.<ref>http://faculty.marianopolis.edu/c.belanger/quebechistory/docs/michaud/09.htm</ref>
The same day, [[Jacques Brassard]], the parliamentary leader of the government at the time, answered also in an open letter to the newspapers,{{Which|date=October 2013}} that the motion was not against Yves Michaud himself, but on his comments made as a public person seeking office in the government. He said that the National Assembly had the right to condemn unacceptable propositions made in a political context. He also stated that freedom of speech was not a one-way proposition.<ref>http://faculty.marianopolis.edu/c.belanger/quebechistory/docs/michaud/18.htm</ref>
The event, which is said to have been a reason for [[Lucien Bouchard]]'s resignation on January 11, 2001,{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}} was not listed in B'nai Brith's annual compilation of anti-semitic events.{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}} During an [https://web.archive.org/web/20041206084118/http://www.voir.ca/actualite/actualite.aspx?iIDArticle=14890 interview for ''Voir'' magazine] for the week of March 1, 2001, Robert Libman stated that he did not think Yves Michaud was an anti-semite and that his remarks had been distorted.
Some less-involved observers in the media{{Who|date=October 2013}} have expressed the view that although Michaud's comments were borderline and controversial as they could be interpreted as trivialization of the Shoah, the comparisons made by his accusers to notable antisemites like [[Ernst Zündel]] were excessive and exaggerated Michaud's intent.{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}}
Michaud has been battling in court to defend his reputation since that time.{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}}

{{Infobox film festival | name = Night Visions | logo = Night Visions Film Festival logo 2014.png | logo_alt = Night Visions Film Festival Logo | logo_size = 200px | image = | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = | opening = | closing = | location = [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] | telephone = | founded = {{start date|1997}} | awardsreceived = Helsinki Cultural Achievement Award (2012) | awards = Night Visions Audience Award | films = | directors = | producers = | writers = | starring = | host = Night Visions - Yön Kuvat Ry | number = | date = '''Back to Basics''': April
'''Maximum Halloween''': October | language = International | website = {{URL|http://www.nightvisions.info}} | chronology = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''Night Visions''' is a biannual [[film festival]] focusing on [[horror film|horror]], [[fantasy]], [[science fiction]] and [[cult film|cult]] [[Film|cinema]]. The festival is held twice a year in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]]. The festival also showcases [[documentary film|documentaries]] and [[short films]]. The first Night Visions festival was organized in November 1997. == History == The first Night Visions festival was organized in Halloween 1997. The roots of the festival lay in Gorehound, a film [[zine]] focusing on genre cinema, whose readership and staff were responsible for the first Night Visions Film Festival. The current festival director Mikko Aromaa is former editor-in-chief of Gorehound. The first festival was a one night event of an overnight screening of genre films showed back to back on one screen.{{cite web|last1=Hokkanen|first1=Melissa|title=Night Visions on mannaa elokuvafanaatikolle|url=http://www.city.fi/kulttuuri/night+visions+on+mannaa+elokuvafanaatikolle/5741|website=City.fi|publisher=City Digital Oy|accessdate=10 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=28 March 2013}} From 2002 onwards, Night Visions film festival has been arranged twice a year, with '''Back to Basics''' in mid-April and '''Maximum Halloween''' on [[Halloween]] weekend. The Maximum Halloween event was extended from one night event to a weekend event in 2005, showing movies on three different nights.{{cite news|title=Night Visions laajenee kolmipäiväiseksi|url=http://www.ts.fi/kulttuuri/1073969115/Night+Visions+laajeneekolmipaivaiseksi|accessdate=10 December 2014|work=[[Turun Sanomat]]|publisher=TS-Yhtymä Oy|date=27 May 2005}} In January 2013 the film festival was awarded the Cultural Achievement Award 2012 from the City of [[Helsinki]]. The festival was credited for its bold, original and first-rate program, along with its unique atmosphere in overnight movie marathons. The judges also added that many of the films would never be seen in [[Finland]] without the festival. The winner was chosen by the Helsinki Board of Culture from nearly thousand nominees.{{cite news|last1=Koppinen|first1=Maija|title=Elokuvafestivaali Night Visions sai Helsingin kulttuuriteko -palkinnon|url=http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/a1305641179805|accessdate=10 December 2014|work=[[Helsingin Sanomat]]|publisher=Sanoma Media Oy|date=24 January 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Natri|first1=Santtu|title=Night Visions palkittiin Helsingissä vuoden kulttuuritekona|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/night_visions_palkittiin_helsingissa_vuoden_kulttuuritekona/6464927|accessdate=10 December 2014|work=[[YLE|YLE Uutiset]]|publisher=Yleisradio Oy|date=24 January 2013}} The 2014 film festival set a new record in attendance when Night Visions reported 8963 total attendees in Maximum Halloween event screenings and other organized events. With 5827 admissions in the same year's Back to Basics event and the one-off Night Visions ShockPoint, a [[gonzo journalism|gonzo]] [[documentary film|documentary]] special, the film festival drew a total audience of 14,790 in 2014.{{cite web|title=Night Visions -festivaali kasvatti jälleen yleisöään|url=http://www.nightvisions.info/?p=4868|website=Nightvisions.info|publisher=Night Visions - Yön Kuvat Ry|accessdate=10 December 2014|date=4 November 2014}}{{cite web|title=Kevään Night Visions -festivaali yleisöennätykseen|url=http://www.nightvisions.info/?p=4114|website=Nightvisions.info|publisher=Night Visions - Yön Kuvat Ry|accessdate=12 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=15 April 2014}} == Program == === Back to Basics === Back to Basics is currently a four night event, climaxing in a marathon event that lasts from evening until early morning, usually screening films on two different screens. Films are played back to back with short intermissions in between. Back to Basics focuses on genre [[classic]]s, showing older movies and underground cult films, with occasional stabs at [[mainstream]] and newer genre pieces. Back to Basics has featured movies such as [[Reefer Madness]], [[The Story of Joanna]], [[The Fountain]], [[The Candy Snatchers]], [[The Last House on the Left (2009 film)|The Last House on the Left]], [[Joysticks (film)|Joysticks]], [[Detroit 9000]], [[The Room (film)|The Room]], [[Five Element Ninjas]], [[The Toxic Avenger (film)|The Toxic Avenger]] and more.{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|title=Night Visions - Back To Basics 2005|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2005/03/004401/night_visions_back_to_basics_2005.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=10 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=6 March 2005}}{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|title=Night Visions - Back To Basics 2006|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2006/04/007201/night_visions_back_to_basics_2006.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=10 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=5 April 2006}}{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|title=Night Visions - Back To Basics 2007|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2007/04/008101/night_visions_back_to_basics_2007.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=10 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=7 April 2007}}{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|last2=Piispanen|first2=Tatu|last3=Määttä|first3=Sakari|title=Night Visions - Back to Basic 2008|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2008/04/009601/night_visions_back_to_basics_2008.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=10 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=10 April 2008}}{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|last2=Määttä|first2=Sakari|last3=Tapionsalo|first3=Lasse|title=Night Visions - Back to Basics 2009|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2009/04/011601/night_visions_back_to_basics_2009.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=10 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=8 April 2009}}{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|title=Night Visions - Back to Basics 2010|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2010/04/013401/night_visions_back_to_basics_2010.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=10 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=19 April 2010}}{{cite web|last1=Suni|first1=Jetro|title=Night Visions - Back to Basics 2011|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2011/05/018001/night_visions_back_to_basics_2011.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=10 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=17 May 2011}}{{cite web|last1=Määttä|first1=Sakari|title=Night Visions - Back to Basics 2012|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2012/05/020301/night_visions_back_to_basics_2012.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=10 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=4 May 2012}}{{cite web|last1=Ihalainen|first1=Paavo|last2=Määttä|first2=Sakari|last3=Helminen|first3=Mika|last4=Karinen|first4=Kalle|last5=Piispanen|first5=Tatu|last6=Tohka|first6=Antti|title=Night Visions - Back to Basics 2013|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2013/06/018301/night_visions_back_to_basics_2013.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=10 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=27 June 2013}}{{cite web|last1=Ihalainen|first1=Paavo|last2=Määttä|first2=Sakari|last3=Meisalmi|first3=Esa|last4=Karinen|first4=Kalle|title=Night Visions - Back to Basics 2014|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2014/04/023801/night_visions_back_to_basics_2014.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=11 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=22 April 2014}} === Maximum Halloween === Maximum Halloween is organized usually as close to Halloween as possible, screening films on multiple screens and theaters. The event focuses on newer genre films and has acted as a premiere venue for many films in [[Finland]]. Maximum Halloween also usually screens a selection of old classics and [[documentary film|documentaries]]. The 2014 Maximum Halloween screened 45 [[feature length]] films and documentaries in three different theaters, along with a selection of short films during the five-day event. The event has featured films such as [[Saw (2004 film)|Saw]], [[The Descent]], [[Reeker]], [[Near Dark]], [[Tokyo Gore Police]], [[The Forbidden Door]], [[The Disappearance of Alice Creed]], [[Profondo Rosso]], [[Shogun Assassin]] and many more along the years.{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|title=Night Visions - Maximum Halloween 3004|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2004/10/003001/night_visions_maximum_halloween_3004.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=11 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=24 October 2004}}{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|title=Night Visions - Maximum Halloween 3005|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2005/11/006701/night_visions_maximum_halloween_3005.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=12 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=1 November 2005}}{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|title=Night Visions - Maximum Halloween 3007|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2007/11/008901/night_visions_maximum_halloween_3007.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=12 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=1 November 2007}}{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|last2=Piispanen|first2=Tatu|last3=Koivisto|first3=Mikko|title=Night Visions - Maximum Halloween 3008|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2008/10/010701/night_visions_maximum_halloween_3008.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=12 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=27 November 2008}}{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|title=Night Visions - Maximum Halloween 3009|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2009/11/012601/night_visions_maximum_halloween_3009.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=12 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=9 November 2009}}{{cite web|last1=Rautsi|first1=Ilja|title=Night Visions - Maximum Halloween 3010|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2010/11/015501/night_visions_maximum_halloween_3010.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=12 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=5 November 2010}}{{cite web|last1=Suni|first1=Jetro|last2=Piispanen|first2=Tatu|last3=Määttä|first3=Sakari|last4=Helminen|first4=Mika|last5=Karinen|first5=Kalle|last6=Meisalmi|first6=Esa|last7=Ihalainen|first7=Paavo|title=Night Visions - Maximum Halloween 3011|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2011/11/014001/night_visions_maximum_halloween_3011.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=12 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=11 November 2011}}{{cite web|last1=Ihalainen|first1=Paavo|title=Night Visions - Maximum Halloween 3012|url=http://www.elitisti.net/artikkeli/2012/11/021201/night_visions_maximum_halloween_3012.html|website=Elitisti.net|accessdate=12 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=23 November 2012}} === Themes and guests === Night Visions has had a varied line-up of guest film-makers and actors during its run. The guests are sometimes associated with the themes of the festival; such as [[Christopher Lee]] and the [[Hammer Film Productions]] theme of the 2002 festival or [[Lloyd Kaufman]] of [[Troma Entertainment]] fame in the 2014 festival. Other special guests have included [[Dario Argento]], [[Paul Verhoeven]], [[John McNaughton]], [[John Waters]] and [[Udo Kier]] among others.{{cite web|last1=Mannila|first1=Annina|title=Elävän kuvan aatelia - Christopher Lee Suomessa|url=http://www.film-o-holic.com/artikkelit/elavan-kuvan-aatelia-christopher-lee-suomessa/|website=Film-o-holic.com|publisher=Filmiverkko Ry|accessdate=12 December 2014|language=Finnish|date=20 April 2002}}{{cite news|title=Kulttielokuva The Toxic Avengerin ohjaaja saapuu Helsinkiin|url=http://www.metro.fi/uutiset/a1387802047234|accessdate=12 December 2014|work=[[Metro International|Metro Helsinki]]|publisher=Sanoma Media Oy|date=9 April 2014}}{{cite web|last1=O'Sullivan|first1=James|title=Night Visions fill Helsinki cinemas|url=http://finland.fi/Public/default.aspx?contentid=314903&nodeid=44498&culture=en-US|website=Finland.fi|publisher=Finland Promotion Board|accessdate=12 December 2014|date=October 2014}} === Other events === In 2014 Night Visions organized an industry afternoon, in collaboration with Nordic Genre Invasion, that featured many upcoming nordic filmmakers as well as industry veterans. The afternoon consisted of movie screenings and panel discussion.{{cite web|title=Nordic Genre Invasion and Night Visions Industry Afternoon in Helsinki Oct 30th|url=http://www.kreanord.org/entrenord/nordic-genre-invasion-and-night-visions-industry-afternoon-helsinki-oct-30th|website=Kreanord.org|publisher=Nordic Council of Ministers|accessdate=10 December 2014}} == Awards == The Night Visions Audience Award has been awarded since 2008 to promote the recognition of genre cinema in [[Finland]] and in other [[nordic countries]]. All movies released in the same year, or the year before, the festival is held are eligible. The winner is decided by the audience in a ballot organized at the Maximum Halloween screenings.{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Owen|title=Festival Report: Helsinki’s NIGHT VISIONS 2014|url=http://www.fangoria.com/new/festival-report-helsinkis-night-visions-2014/|website=Fangoria.com|publisher=[[Fangoria]] - The Brooklyn Company Ltd|accessdate=9 December 2014|date=5 November 2014}} The 2013 winner, [[Frank Pavich|Frank Pavich's]] [[documentary film]] [[Jodorowsky's Dune]], was the first [[non-fiction]] film to win the award.{{cite web|last1=Zimmerman|first1=Samuel|title="JODOROWSKY’S DUNE" is Tops at Helsinki’s Night Visions|url=http://www.fangoria.com/new/jodorowskys-dune-is-tops-at-helsinkis-night-visions/|website=Fangoria.com|publisher=[[Fangoria]] - The Brooklyn Company Ltd|accessdate=9 December 2014|date=7 November 2013}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Night Visions Audience Award winners |- ! {{Infobox historical event |Event_Name = Padre Canyon Incident |Image_Name = |Imagesize = |Image_Alt = |Image_Caption = |Thumb_Time = |AKA = |Participants = |Location = Near [[Leupp, Arizona|Leupp]], [[Arizona]], [[United States]] |Date = November 11, 1899 |nongregorian = |Deaths = 3 |Result = |URL = }} {{Navajo Wars}} {{Campaignbox American Indian Wars (1898–1918)}}
The '''Padre Canyon incident''' was a skirmish in November 1899 between a group of [[Navajo people|Navajo]] hunters and a [[Posse comitatus (common law)|posse]] of [[Arizona]] lawmen. Among other things, it was significant in that it nearly started a large-scale [[American Indian Wars|Indian war]] in [[Coconino County, Arizona|Coconino County]] and it led to the expansion of the [[Navajo Reservation]]. It was also the final armed conflict during a land dispute between the Navajo and American settlers, as well as one of the bloodiest.<ref name="azdailysun.com">{{Cite web | title=MNA exhibit revives memory of Padre Canyon Incident of 1899| work=Betsy Bruner| url=http://azdailysun.com/article_c054bb54-3c54-523f-85b3-e87dbd099a37.html| accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref><ref name="hkhinc.com">{{Cite web | title=Two Guns, Arizona by Gladwell Richardson| work=Gladwell Richardson| url=http://www.hkhinc.com/arizona/twoguns/platinum.htm| accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Iverson, pg. 71-76">{{cite book | last=Iverson| first=Peter| authorlink=|author2=Monty Roessel| title=Diné: A History of the Navajos| publisher=University of New Mexico Press| series=| year=2001| doi=| isbn=9780826327154}} </ref>
==Background== In the 1880s and 1890s, the Navajo band of [[Tribal chief|Chief]] B'ugoettin were fighting a minor, undeclared war with local [[Cowman (profession)|cattlemen]] for control of what was later known as the Leupp Extension, a large area of rangeland between Flagstaff, the [[Hopi Reservation]], and the [[Colorado River]], which would later become part of the Navajo Reservation. When the trouble began, the Leupp Extension was owned by the [[Atlantic and Pacific Railroad]], which acquired the land from the federal government through a [[Land grant|grant]]. Like other railroads in the [[American Frontier|Old West]], the Atlantic and Pacific sold unused land to [[American pioneer|pioneers]], but, due to the Navajo presence in the Leupp Extension, pioneers were reluctant to buy land from them.<ref name="hkhinc.com"/><ref name="Iverson, pg. 71-76"/><ref name="landgrant.org">{{Cite web | title=Railroad land grant forfeiture by George Draffan| work=George Draffan| url=http://www.landgrant.org/forfeiture.html| accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
Eventually, cattlemen began moving their herds into the area, which only added tension to an already uneasy situation. Initially, the Navajo pleaded to the federal government for their help, but when that failed they retaliated by raiding for livestock. The cattlemen responded in a like manner, but for the most part the violence was minimal. Usually, when the Navajo captured a thief they would beat him up and then send him on his way. As was the case in 1899.<ref name="azdailysun.com"/><ref name="hkhinc.com"/><ref name="Iverson, pg. 71-76"/>
William Henry Montgomery was a nineteen-year-old [[cowboy]] employed by William Roden, Jr. According to some accounts, on November 6, Montgomery was caught trying to steal some ponies from a group of Navajo hunters so three of the natives assaulted him in the usual manner. Wanting revenge, Montgomery went to Flagstaff and persuaded the county to have warrants issued for the arrest of the three natives. Other accounts say that the posse was responding to allegations of deer [[poaching]] and the theft of horses from William Roden's ranch, but the exact cause for the issuing of the warrants remains uncertain.<ref name="azdailysun.com"/><ref name="hkhinc.com"/><ref name="Iverson, pg. 71-76"/><ref name="newspaperarchive.com1">{{Cite web | title=Newark Daily Advocate, November 13, 1899 : Front Page : NewspaperARCHIVE.com| work=| url=https://newspaperarchive.com/newark-daily-advocate/1899-11-13/| accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
To serve the warrants, [[Deputy Sheriff]] Dan Hogan formed a posse consisting of himself, William Montgomery, William Roden and Walter Durham, who was another cowboy from the Roden Ranch.<ref name="hkhinc.com"/>
==Incident== On the morning of November 11, Hogan and Montgomery left Flagstaff and headed to the Roden Ranch, where they recruited Roden and Durham. From there the posse went east towards Padre Canyon. Later that afternoon, at the edge of Elliott Canyon, the posse spotted a small Navajo camp in the brush down below near the junction of Padre Canyon and [[Canyon Diablo (canyon)|Canyon Diablo]]. After dismounting and making their way down the canyon wall, they stealthily advanced on a [[Wigwam|wickiup]] that was occupied by an elderly man who was [[Buckskin (leather)|tanning]] deer hide.<ref name="azdailysun.com"/><ref name="hkhinc.com"/>
At this time, four other Navajo men spotted Montgomery as they were walking back to camp from a hunting trip. Assuming he was there to steal horses, the Navajos immediately opened fire on Montgomery, striking him in the heart and killing him instantly. A shootout ensued and it was later described by the ''Coconino Sun'' as being "one of the most desperate conflicts ever to be fought in the Southwest."<ref name="hkhinc.com"/><ref name="Iverson, pg. 71-76"/>
The Navajo fire was accurate so the posse was forced to retreat at sundown. Fearing they would be too exposed by climbing back up the canyon wall, the possemen made their way south to a nearby railroad and on the following morning they succeeded in stopping a train for a ride back to Flagstaff.<ref name="hkhinc.com"/>
Two of the Navajos were killed and one other was wounded. Deputy Hogan received a "long gash" across his shoulders as he was bending over to take cover and Roden received a shot to the groin. Montgomery was dead and Durham escaped with the other survivors unharmed.<ref name="azdailysun.com"/><ref name="hkhinc.com"/><ref name="newspaperarchive.com1"/><ref name="newspaperarchive.com2">{{Cite web | title=Eau Claire Leader , November 14, 1899 : Front Page : NewspaperARCHIVE.com| work=| url=https://newspaperarchive.com/eau-claire-leader/1899-11-14/| accessdate=September 1, 2012}}</ref>
==Aftermath== News of the shooting quickly spread throughout Arizona and the rest of the nation, but it took nearly a month before the federal government responded. During that time, both the Navajo and the Americans feared that the other side would launch a campaign of reprisal. As result, Flagstaff was fortified by the town [[militia]].<ref name="azdailysun.com"/><ref name="hkhinc.com"/>
Eventually, the hunters who were involved in the fight were told to report to Flagstaff for a hearing in court, which they refused to do at first. Instead, Chief B'ugoettin assembled 300 heavily armed warriors and led them to Flagstaff. His plan was to conceal his force in the woods outside of town and then go in unarmed with two men to return the posse's horses, attacking only if they were placed in jail. Fortunately, however, [[Reverend]] William R. Johnston helped defuse the situation and he promised B'ugoettin that the three hunters would receive an adequate defense if they surrendered now. B'ugoettin agreed so the attack on Flagstaff never came.<ref name="azdailysun.com"/>
The trial was held in the Coconino County Courthouse in September 1900, during which, the wounded Navajo hunter, Haastiin Biwoo Adin, impressed [[Judge]] [[Richard E. Sloan]] with his address so much so that he found all three of the hunters innocent. Reverend Johnston's nine-year-old son, [[Philip Johnston (code talker)|Philip]], translated the Navajo's speech for the court.<ref name="azdailysun.com"/><ref name="Iverson, pg. 71-76"/>
After the trial, a Navajo delegation was sent to [[Washington, D. C.]] to petition the government for the creation of the Leupp Extension. Ultimately, the delegation was successful in convincing [[President of the United States|President]] [[Theodore Roosevelt]], who issued his executive order on November 14, 1901. The Leupp Extension was named after Roosevelt's commissioner of Indian affairs, [[Bureau of Indian Affairs#Commissioners and Assistant Secretaries|Francis E. Leupp]], and it led to the founding of the town [[Leupp, Arizona|Leupp]]. Also, B'ugoettin rewarded Reverend Johnston by permitting him to build a [[Mission (Christianity)|mission]] at Tolchaco, which was located about seven miles south of Leupp.<ref name="azdailysun.com"/>

Ken | mute = | setting = [[Bowery]], New York City | premiere = {{Start date|2009|12|03}} | place = [[Donmar Warehouse]], London | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = | genre = Drama | web = }} '''''Red''''' is a play by American writer [[John Logan (writer)|John Logan]] about artist [[Mark Rothko]] first produced by the [[Donmar Warehouse]], London, on December 8, 2009. The original production was directed by [[Michael Grandage]] and performed by [[Alfred Molina]] as Rothko and [[Eddie Redmayne]] as his fictional assistant Ken.Mohr, Betty. [http://southtownstar.suntimes.com/entertainment/mohr/8269587-452/red-is-a-larger-than-life-portrait-of-rothko.html "''Red'' is a larger-than-life portrait of Rothko"], ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''. October 19, 2011Shenton, Mark.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/135100-Alfred-Molina-Stars-in-Donmar-Warehouse-Premiere-of-Logans-Red-Opening-Dec-8 "Alfred Molina Stars in Donmar Warehouse Premiere of Logan's ''Red'', Opening Dec. 8"], ''[[Playbill]]'', December 8, 2009[http://www.donmarwarehouse.com/pl103.html "''Red'' listing"], [[Donmar Warehouse]], retrieved May 25, 2010 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100311083827/http://www.donmarwarehouse.com/pl103.html |date=March 11, 2010 }} The production, with its two leads, transferred to [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[John Golden Theatre]] for a limited engagement which began on March 11, 2010, and closed on June 27.Hetrick, Adam and Jones, Kenneth.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/138364-Red-with-Alfred-Molina-and-Eddie-Redmayne-Splashes-Onto-Broadway "''Red'', with Alfred Molina and Eddie Redmayne, Splashes Onto Broadway"], ''[[Playbill]]'', April 1, 2010 It was the 2010 [[Tony Award]] winner for [[Tony Award for Best Play|Best Play]]. Additionally, Redmayne won a 2010 Tony Award for [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Featured Actor in a Play|Best Performance by a Featured Actor in a Play]].{{cite web|title=Who's Nominated?|url=http://www.tonyawards.com/en_US/nominees/index.html|work=Tony Awards|accessdate=13 June 2010}} {{failed verification|date=February 2018}} ==Synopsis== "There is only one thing I fear in life, my friend... One day the black will swallow the red." [[Mark Rothko#Seagram Murals–Four Seasons restaurant commission|Mark Rothko]] is in his New York studio in 1958/59, having been commissioned to paint a group of murals for the expensive and exclusive [[The Four Seasons Restaurant|Four Seasons restaurant]]. He gives orders to his assistant, Ken, as he mixes the paints, makes the frames, and paints the canvases. Ken, however, brashly questions Rothko's theories of art and his acceding to work on such a commercial project. For his part, Rothko dislikes the rise of [[pop art]]. Ultimately, Rothko stops working on the project and decides to return the money. He explains to Ken that the Four Seasons is an inappropriate place for his murals to be seen. ==Reception== Reviews for the London production were mixed for the play but positive for Molina's performance. [[Michael Billington (critic)|Michael Billington]] in ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote: "Alfred Molina, with his large frame and beetling eyebrows, has exactly the fierce intensity of an artist whose paintings were a dynamic battle between [[Apollo and Dionysus]]".[https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2009/dec/09/theatre-review-red-donmar-warehouse "Review: ''Red''"] by [[Michael Billington (critic)|Michael Billington]], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 9 December 2009 In reviewing the Broadway production, [[Michael Kuchwara]] of the [[Associated Press]] wrote: "They are the tantalizing first words of ''Red'', John Logan's engrossing, often enthralling new play about art, an artist and the act of creation." Those first words were "What do you see?" ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' wrote that "Alfred Molina is majestic".[http://www.didhelikeit.com/shows/red-review.html "''Red'' reviews"], didhelikeit.com, retrieved May 22, 2010 ==Awards and nominations== The play won the 2010 [[Drama League Award]] for Distinguished Production of a Play and Molina won the Distinguished Performance Award.Gans, Andrew.[http://www.playbill.com/article/sondheim-red-bridge-la-cage-and-molina-win-drama-league-awards-com-168631 "''Sondheim'', ''Red'', ''Bridge'', ''La Cage'' and Molina Win Drama League Awards"], ''[[Playbill]]'', May 21, 2010. Accessed 11 February 2018. The play was nominated for a total of seven [[Tony Award]]s, winning six, including: Best Play, Best Featured Actor in a Play for Eddie Redmayne, Best Direction of a Play for Michael Grandage, Best Scenic Design of a Play for [[Christopher Oram]], Best Lighting Design of a Play for Neil Austin, and Best Sound Design of a Play for Adam Cork. In addition, Alfred Molina was nominated for the [[Tony Award for Best Actor in a Play]] for his role as Mark Rothko. All in all, it received the most wins out of any other production that season. The play also won the [[Drama Desk Award]] for Outstanding Play while Grandage and Austin were honoured with Drama Desk Awards for their work. Molina, Cork and Oram were also similarly nominated.Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/article/red-memphis-bridge-fences-and-la-cage-win-drama-desk-awards-com-168661 "''Red'', ''Memphis'', ''Bridge'', ''Fences'' and ''La Cage'' Win Drama Desk Awards"], ''[[Playbill]]'', May 23, 2010. Accessed 11 February 2018. ==Other productions== [[File:Red (play).jpg|upright=2|thumb|Christopher Oram, Alfred Enoch, Michael Grandage, Alfred Molina in 2018 on the set of ''Red'' at the Wyndham's Theatre]] In October 2013, the play premiered in Chile at [[Centro Mori]] Bellavista theatre under the title ''Rojo'', starring Luis Gnecco and Martin Bacigalupo, directed by Rodrigo Sepúlveda and produced by The Cow Company.{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} Geva Theatre Center in Rochester, New York, mounted a production of ''Red'' in October/November 2015, starring Stephen Caffrey as Mark Rothko and John Ford-Dunker as Ken. Directed by Skip Greer, the production featured scenic design by Robert Koharchik, costume design by Ann M. Emo, lighting design by Kendall Smith and sound design by Dan Roach.{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} ''Red'' played in the Pit at the [[New National Theatre Tokyo]] from August to October 2015, starring [[Tetsushi Tanaka]] as Rothko and [[Shun Oguri]] as Ken, directed by Eriko Ogawa.Nobuko Tanaka, [http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2015/08/20/stage/shun-oguri-faces-off-artistic-master-red/ "Shun Oguri faces off with an artistic master in ''Red''"], ''[[The Japan Times]]'', August 20, 2015. Retrieved January 09, 2016. In October, 2016 the play opened at The Junction in Dubai before transferring to the JamJar. The production starred Osman Aboubakr as Rothko and Deepak Venugopal as Ken, with direction by [[Alex Broun]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} In July/August 2017, the play was mounted at the Cape Playhouse in [[Dennis, Massachusetts]]. Stephen Caffrey starred as Mark Rothko and Patrick Stafford as Ken, with direction by David Glenn Armstrong.{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}} The play was revived from May to July 2018 at the [[Wyndham's Theatre]] in London's [[West End theatre|West End]], directed by Michael Grandage with [[Alfred Enoch]], and Alfred Molina reprising his original role.[https://www.londontheatre1.com/news/192651/full-casting-announced-for-the-lieutenant-of-inishmore/ "Full casting announced for ''The Lieutenant of Inishmore''"], London Theatre 1, January 12, 2018 ==Works referenced in the play== The play references other works of art: * ''[[The Birth of Tragedy]]'' by [[Friedrich Nietzsche]].[https://www.canadianstage.com/ArticleMedia/pdfs/Education/Study_Guides/Red%20-%20Study%20Guide.pdf Study Guide: ''Red''], Erin Schachter, Jessica Warnock, Brendon Allen, Kevin Parkin, [[Canadian Stage]], 2011 File:Cappella cerasi, caravggio, conversione di saulo, 1601.JPG|"I go to the [[Santa Maria del Popolo]] to see [[Caravaggio]]’s ’[[The Conversion of Saint Paul (Caravaggio)|Conversion of Saul]],’ which turns out is tucked away in a dark corner of this dark church with no natural light. It’s like a cave. But the painting glowed!". File:Atelier rouge matisse 1.jpg|''[[The Red Studio]]'' by [[Matisse]] File:Rembrandt - Belshazzar's Feast - WGA19123.jpg|''[[Belshazzar's Feast (Rembrandt)|Belshazzar's Feast]]'' by [[Rembrandt]]. File:Laurentian Library vestibule.jpg|The vestibule of the [[Laurentian Library]] by [[Michelangelo]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IBDB title|486438|Red}} *Probst, Andy. [http://www.theatermania.com/london/news/12-2009/review-roundup-red-with-alfred-molina-at-donmar-wa_23450.html "Review Roundup: ''Red'', with Alfred Molina, at Donmar Warehouse"], theatermania.com, December 10, 2009 * [https://ensembletheatre.com/images/feature/Red_Website_05_15-1.pdf Behind the Scenes: ''Red'', by John Logan]. {{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=May 2016}} {{Notability|date=April 2011}} }} {{Infobox newspaper |name = Sha'ar LaMathil |logo = Shaar-logo.gif |type = [[Weekly newspaper]] |language = [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] |publishing_country = Israel |foundation = 1956 |ceased publication = 2012 }} '''''Sha’ar LaMatchil''''' (in [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] '''שער למתחיל''', ''Gateway for the Beginner''), was a weekly [[Israel]]i newspaper written in easy [[Hebrew]]. Publication has ceased as of April 2012 and it remains unclear if and when the paper will return.
The weekly was founded in 1956 by the "Department for Language Endowment" of the [[Israeli Ministry of Education]]. The newspaper is intended for [[olim]] and other newcomers to Israel who are learning the [[Hebrew Language]], and is also designed for those who are studying Hebrew at an [[ulpan]]. The newspaper addresses many different topics in varying degrees of language complexity. It is written with [[nikud]]ot and a large [[typeface]].
The newspaper is edited in [[Tel Aviv]], and is part of the [[Yediot Ahronot]] publishing group.
== History == The newspaper was founded in the 1950s and initially comprised two separate newspapers: "Gateway" and "To Begin." In 1978 the two newspapers were combined under a new name. The newspaper was originally published by the [[Jerusalem Post]] before it was transferred to [[Yedioth Ahronot]]. In 2012 the newspaper was discontinued and is no longer published.
==Digital Edition==
In January 2009, Sha’ar La’Matchil launched an online version.
In addition to written articles, the digital edition contains audio files of selected articles, which are recorded in clear Hebrew to help learners of the language.
==External links== * http://www.shaaronline.com/eng/ * [http://www.slamathil.co.il Sha’ar LaMathil website] * [http://ae.lms.education.gov.il/course/view.php?id=396 Ministry of Education of Israel Archives]
